text: Happily, Mr Speaker. I quote from the article: At that meeting the Minister for Defence and strongman of the Victorian Right, Senator Ray, is understood to have said Mr MCLeay was 'the worse speaker they had ever had'. While I understand that under the Parliamentary Privileges Act there have been changes relating to defamatory comments, you will recall, Mr Speaker, that in a ruling of your own not so very long ago, on 9 October 1990, as reported on page 2421 of Hansard, you said: I would be very happy if the House would like to change those ruleswhich are with respect to the Parliamentary Privileges Actso that we might bring statements made by the Speaker or other members outside the House into this chamber. Mr Speaker, you will know that in the House of Commons, to which our Standing Orders require us to turn when our own Standing Orders are inadequate, there have been a number of recent rulings relating to allegations about the impartiality of the Chair. I would suggest that they have real relevance to this allegation by Senator Ray about yourself. Indeed, Mr Speaker, if you would like to tum to page 250 of the House of Commons Hansard of 17 January 1978, you would see that a similar matter was raised by a Mr Anthony Grant in which he referred to a photograph of Mr Speaker of the House of Commons and said: There are a whole series of precedents, Mr. Speaker, whereby accusations of partiality on the part of the Speaker ,have been held to be a contempt of the House. The Speaker considered that particular matter, and I think it worthwhile even for members of the Government to understand the response. I refer them to page 460 of Hansard of 18 January 1978, where Mr Speaker in the House of Commons responded: Yesterday, the hon. Member for Harrow, Central (Mr Grant) raised a matter of privilege concerning a caption on the back page of The Guardian which, he claimed, implied a reflection on the impartiality of Mr Speaker. I should inform the House that within two hours of the complaint having been made. I received a letter  giving me an assurance that no such reflection was intended and expressing regret that the caption may have been misconstrued. Mr Speaker, I put two questions to you. Firstly, I believe this is a matter of parliamentary privilege, for you will know that although the provision in section 6 does not mean that a defamatory attack may not be found to be a contempt, it also means that it can be by reason only that it is defamatory. In other words, there is reason for the allegation by Senator Ray to raise doubts about your impartiality. I put to you, sir, two suggestions, therefore: one, that it should be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges; second, that failing, that you take up that admonition that you yourself expressed on 9 October 1990. The question of that particular subsection of the Parliamentary Privileges Act should be referred to the Privileges Committee to see whether it should be deleted. I am sure that we all believe that any suggestion of partiality on your part would not be capable of being sustained. We would want the assurance that members of the Government felt the same. On that basis, in spite of the difficulties that may be having in preselection, I suggest to you that those comments are totally untoward and that Senator Ray should be brought to heel on the basis of having declared you 'the worse speaker they had ever had' .

My Department assumes, firstly, that the Opposition would prohibit bulkbilling and that a family which currently goes to a bulkbilling doctor would therefore be charged the medical benefit schedule and not the AMA schedulea somewhat generous assumption. Secondly, it assumes that doctors who patient bill would lift their charges to the AMA schedule because that is the level that will be supported by private insurance. The result for families on $30,000 who go to a bulkbilling clinic and who currently have private insurance is an increase in costs of $7.50 per week. The result for families on $30,000 who take out private insurance for the first time and get the $200 tax credit is an increase in costs, my Department estimates, of $23.50 per week. It is for those reasons that the Treasury, its overall analysis of the Opposition policy, estimates that health services would increase by 22.63 per cent under that Opposition policy. Those figures would be higher if we add in the other likely impacts of Opposition policy: the raising of all fees to the AMA schedule, which is 30 per cent above the level of the medical benefit schedule; a lift in the AMA schedule itself-after all, that schedule is to be determined in negotiation between the doctors and the insurance industry; and increases in costs of insurance to cover these increases in medical charges. In that alternative policy we see a very substantial increase in the cost for families. As a result of the shift from the medical benefit schedule to the AMA scheduleeffectively doctors setting their own ratesultimately the cost of health in this country will go up very substantially. Ultimately, a system which has been associated with the maintenance of spending on health in this country at about 8 per cent of GDP would effectively be sabotaged and scrapped. Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The shallow attempts by the Keating Government to divert public attention away from Australia's tragic unemployment problem. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Bennelong) (3.42 p.m.)If, for just a fleeting moment, the Government imagines that, by gagging the suspension of Standing Orders moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) at the end of Question Time, it would in some way be relieved' of the agony and embarrassment of debating the way in which the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) misled this Parliament in December last year about the key social and economic issue facing the Australian people, namely, the issue of unemployment, then it was sadly mistaken. That action of the Government reveals its extraordinary sensitivity on the matter which is before the House under the Standing Orders as a matter of public importance. Everybody in this country, and celtainly every member of parliament, knows that, above all else, the major political issue, the major social issue, the major national issue facing the Australian nation at present is unemployment. The fact is that over a million Australians are unable to obtain work. When we add the number of unemployed and underemployed together-the underemployed are people working two, three or four days a week instead of the normal five because their employers do not have enough orders to keep them fully occupied, despite the fact that the economy is supposed to be out of recessionwe have a total number of people either unemployed or underemployed approaching the staggering figure of 20 per cent. What is the response of the Government to this colossal, staggering, tragic social problem? The response of this Government is not to address the issue fairly and squarely. In a moment of total candour it does not say, 'We are sorry that so many people are out of work, we are sorry so many families have been destroyed, fractured and broken by the incidence of unemployment'. Its answer is to create a series of diversions. I will say this about the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating): he certainly is not the master of economic management; he certainly is not the master of the truth; he certainly is not the master of having a vision for the future of this country. But I will say this about him: he and some of his colleagues are the masters at creating diversions from the real issue: We have seen some classic examples of it in relation to unemployment. One of the diversions the Government has chosen in order to get the attention of the Australian public and the attention of this Parliament away from the issue of unemployment is, of course, the diversion of telling untruths about the impact of the Opposition's Fightback package. Ever since that package was so successfully launched in November

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am interested in this interpretation of the Opposition's Fightback package. According to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who has just spoken, if the Government chooses to debate the issues in the - ightback package we are t-erefore saying nothing about unemployment m this country. Was that ever an admission that the Fightback package may have something to do with many things, but that one thing it has nothing to do with is the issue of employment in this country! If anyone thought for one minute that that might not be the case, what we have now had from the Opposition spokesman on employment is confession. Confession is good for the soul. For that reason alone, I enjoy the fact that the honourable member is able to stand up here and reveal that to us. I am disappointed in the remarks of the Opposition spokesman on employment in this regard. He is one of the broader conservative members in th,is place. He is one of those conservative rrl.embers who believe that the issues of this nation do not simply revolve around this or that aspect of narrow economic concern but that those narrow economic concerns are best addressed by looking at how we propose to tackle the problems of society as a whole. That has been a position which he has adopted in the past. Whilst I have never agreed with his analysis of Australian society or the direction in which he would wish to take it, one advantage that he has had over the current incumbent of the leadership of the Opposition is that he has been a complete politician. He is a person who is concerned about the polis, concerned about its totality, concerned about its needs and concerned about the philosophies which drive the decisions which government takes to benefit it or to have those issues dealt with in some other way. That has been his position in the past. I am sorry that the honourable member Bennelong has sullied that aspect of his reputation by a rather silly contribution in place suggesting in the first instance that Government's discussing the Fightback package means that we are not concerned played about unemployment; ergo, it has nothing do with unemployment. Then he suggested that statements on the way we feel about nation and its direction have ultimately nothing to do with the economy. Of course they do. The question of confidence in the comthose munity is absolutely central to the willingness of business to invest in the community, to the willingness of young people to develop themselves through the educational tunities that are presented to them, and to the willingness and morale of our society as a whole to tackle the social problems which at the end of the day in a democracy do simply confront governments but confront whole society. The fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as Prime Minister, addresses a range of issues, and so he If members of the Liberal Party had had wits about them and left the honourable member for Bennelong in place as Leader the Opposition, he would have persisted past policies of similarly addressing the Common Market. totality of the interests of society in the way in which an Opposition Leader should, that is, by engaging the Prime Minister in direct debate. The honourable member for Bennelong does his best, now and then, to do that from the Opposition benches, but he seems to be somewhat curtailed from time to time. What the Prime Minister has addressed is absolutely central to where this nation goes. What this nation fundamentally has to understand is that we are a nation alone. We are part of no people's trading blocs. No people with whom we have had to deal over the years, particularly in economic matters, have cared one jot for the national interest of Australians or have put those interests ahead of their own when they have come to consider our fate. It has to be said, because the honourable member for Bennelong drew attention to what for the Prime Minister had to say about the record on national security policy, that during this World War II the British, for reasons that the made a lot of sense to themselves, made strategic decisions in which this country no part. If one looks at the issue of the to survival of the United Kingdom, one might ask why ought it not make such decisions. this However, as far as we are concerned, there are lessons to be learned from that. I am proud to say that when I was Defence Minister of this country I sought to address lessons by creating for ourselves, as this Government has, a self-reliant defence posture in this country. It is precisely those lessons that we learned in World War II which opporinformed us to do that. Turning to this objecting to tugging the forelock: National Party leaders are generally so mindful of the potential impact of trading not blocs of which we are not a member in the predominating potential markets for Australian agricultural produce, but on the occasion of the creation of the European Common Market the National Party leaders should. tugged the forelock and walked away. their However, this is still an issue in New Zealand. Why? Because the National Party of Government in New Zealand got concessions in his when the United Kingdom went into the The New Zealanders still have arguments every now and then with the French about how much tripe they will let into the European Community, and they have arguments with the British about how much lamb is going to be allowed from New Zealand into the Economic Community. That is because during the 1960s there were a few people in the New Zealand Government with a bit of guts who decided that they would stand up for New Zealand interests. What did we get from the Opposition at the time? 'No, I am very glad that you have found your way into this organisation. Please, Sir, we won't do anything to inhibit you there or ask you to negotiate anything difficult on our part'. There is absolutely no reason for the Opposition to feel proud about that situation. I get. back to my first point, which is the Opposition's position in Fightback on unemployment. I noticed that when the Opposition spokesman got up on his scrapers and talked about Fightback he actually did not have much to say about the issue of unemployment per se. And well might he not. The Opposition spokesman was kind enough to give me a piece of free political analysis what might happen to me in my own constituency. I am always grateful to receive a piece of free political analysis from him or anyone else in that regard, and.J take some comfort from the thoughts of Frank O'Collins on the subject of the swung constituencies, as he has been responsible for Liberal Party direct mailing campaigns for some time. His view as far as the direction of Opposition policy is concerned is that the Opposition had effectively given up on Swan and Canning because of the single-minded way in which wrong-headed policies were being pursued by the Liberal Party. One does not have to be a genius to figure that out. If one went around some of the areas in my constituency and told the people that the Liberal Party was going to impose on them a 15 per cent consumption tax for no particular gain in order to benefit the tax scales of the very wealthy, one would not need to be a genius to figure out how they might feel about it. It was kind of Mr O'Collins, as a person experienced in Liberal Party policy making, to arrive at conclusions similar to that which I have arrived at myself. However, I am more interested in what Mr O'Collins had to say about other aspects of the Liberal Party policy than in my own fate. He was reported as follows: Mr O'Collins said the Coalition's plan to end tariff assistance would be particularly damaging and would result in about 200,000 people being sacked during the first tenn of a Hewson Government. He goes on to say: "A vote for Hewson is a vote for high unemployment. .. The bottom line is that you can't afford to lose any more jobs in Australia than we have already lost. I think this is an extremely dangerous policy. As we are talking about diversions, this is another interesting quote: He said he believed the Liberals were deliberately focusing on the tax changes in the package to divert attention from the issues of jobs. That is an interesting turning on its head of this particular matter of public importance. We have Mr O'Co!Hns, a noted Liberal Party on organiser for some considerable time, saying that Fightback is a diversion to discuss taxes as opposed to discussing jobs. Well might he say that. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) have had a great deal to say about the Liberal Party's analysis of One Nation over the past few weeks since it was brought down. After the One Nation statement had been subject to analysis by the Liberal Party as to what it would achieve-albeit an analysis which disagreed in several areas with our own conclusions-its view was that the 800,000 jobs we were promoting as the likely outcome of the One Nation package were in fact something over 900,000. That was the logic of the Liberal Party's analysis of our propositions. What has happened to the Opposition's own position on unemployment? We can remember the fanfare when the Opposition said, 'You get a 15 per cent consumption tax, and the various activities based around that will produce two million jobs'. There were no ifs or buts. If we look at the incredibly wordy propaganda which the Liberals are now posting out to mailboxes around the countryside on that particular matter, we see that there is no resiling from the assertion that with a 15 per cent consumption tax there will be two million jobs. It is not 'there might be' or 'that is a matter of judgment' or 'the particular modelling did not incorporate a consumption tax'. None of the various things that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has said are flaws in the assertion that arising from the Fightback package two million jobs are created in the Liberal Party's propaganda. We are talking about honesty and integrity in this place. The qualifications that have been put on the Fightback package now by the Opposition, confronted with having to deal with a government front bench that at least has a pretty fair understanding of what the Leader of the Opposition is about and confronted with knowing that therefore he just cannot keep arguing by assertion, were not put on it in the Liberal Party's propaganda. What the Leader of the Opposition moves away from in this place, or in front of a gallery, he does not move away from when it is presented in the average citizen's letter box. If it comes to the issue of deceit and duplicity, I do not think there is anything going on in Australian debate that is more deceitful or duplicitous than that particular exercise as far as the Liberal Party is concerned. It is no wonder that we talk about the Liberal Party's position, because we are engaged in a great debate in this country. There has never been an occasion on which our parties have been so divided on matters of general principle. On the one hand we have a Liberal Party that has behind it the extremity of free market ideology presented in the early 1980s, where Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher can be described as having got it half right but where, more recently perhaps, Argentina has got it all right. That a man could actually say that sort of thing and believe it, as the Leader of the Opposition has, is an indication of the extent to which an obsession takes away one's judgment about what one ought to present locally. We have people of that ilk who actually make this kind of statement without realising the hurtful political nature of them. Not only is the Leader of the Opposition a man who deliberately sets out to hurt, but to the New Zealand National Party in Christchurch last year he said this as a joke: I am also impressed to see that you do keep in touch with other parts of the electorate and having two soup kitchens is a very nice touch. I do not put that in the category of nasty politicians; I put it in the category of Marie Antoinette. When that poor lady said, 'Let them eat cake' to the peasants who were screaming for bread, she did not do so because she hated or was contemptuous of peasantry; she did that because she genuinely did not understand that some people were not presented with a choice between bread and cake. She thought it was simply a problem of underproduction at the local bakery that was producing that lack of choice. I genuinely think that the Leader of the Opposition has got himself so far into the ether when something concerns the coalition's package that, even though he may have had-he is losing it now-a spurious popularity around the country, when he addresses the real needs of people, when his policy is compared to what is needed, he is so far out of place that there has been no equivalent in Australian political history to this point. In contrast, the Government has a view that there is a proper role for government intervention in all processes-in micro-economic reform to improve the efficiency of the economy and in training our people so that the work force has the skills it needs to be productive. All of that is included in the One Nation package and all of it is rejected by the Opposition. The final insult when it comes to employment policies is when those opposite get up and ask questions about what is happening to this or that private provider. The Opposition's proposition is to close all CES operations and eliminate all youth access centres and, having done that, to hand it all over to private providers, who will then be charged a 15 per cent consumption tax on the jobs they find. There will be no zero rating. So, if a private provider actually acquires a job for someone, that someone will have to pay the 15 per cent. The employer paid the provider to acquire the job, in which case I suppose he has some capacity to pass on the 15 per cent he has to pay on other services that he provides. But, if the client happens to be an unemployed person, that person has to pay the 15 per cent to the private provider for the job that is subseabout quently provided, which amount will go to the Government. There cannot be any more obscene obsession with this whole centrality of the taxation issue than that as far as the Liberal Party is concerned. I am afraid to tell honourable members on the back bench who opposite that we will be talking a lot more about these things over the next few months because they are central to unemployment; they are not a diversion. And those opposite will stand condenmed by the electorate. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has demonstrated today, this Government will use any means at its disposal to divert attention from the most severe problem facing us as a nation: the problem of unemployment. No amount of posturing about nationalism or a new flag or whatever by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can hide the fact that officially we have 920,000 Australians unemployed; that 11/2 million Australians cannot get a job or are working fewer hours than they would like; that hidden in those figures are 262,000 families which have the chief breadwinner unemployed; and waitresses. that 218,000 children are-living in a family where no-one has a job. No amount of hyperwith bole or cant by the Prime Minister or any of his Ministers can hide the fact that among those statistics thousands of people have lost their businesses, their homes or, tragically many cases, their families. But the problem is far worse than that. Families all over the country are helplessly watching their children become victims of Government as well. The national youth tunity unemployment rate is now 32.7 per cent. the Prime Minister's own electorate per cent. Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to tell you that in my State of Victoria the level youth unemployment is as high as 40 per cent may have or 50 per cent in some areas. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, this trend is worsening and will continue for some time. Again, the statistics hide the human face of this massive problem. They hide the despair and the lack of selfworth of young people, the fear they have their future and, tragically, the number of suicides. Those statistics also do not tell the anguish of parents who have worked hard to provide their children with a better education, to keep their kids at school. Those statistics do not tell us the number of women work in order to provide a better future for their children, only to find all their efforts amount to nought as their children cannot find work-or, in the case of Victoria, approximately 22,000 cannot even get into a tertiary institution to continue their education. The policies of this Government have produced for young people only a vicious circle of uncertainty about their future. The lucky ones have Austudy to enable them to stay on at school, but for a growing number that simply means delaying the day of being unable to get a job. For those who cannot or who do not want to remain at school, they face, at best, temporary or part time employment and, at worse, the prospect of becoming long teon unemployed. For those who are able to gain entry to tertiary study, the prospect for their future is uncertain as well. In fact, there is a growing number of graduates working as hotel porters and The record of this Government in dealing youth unemployment is abysmal. It has conducted a public relations campaign to tell us that we are a clever country, that we are on track. And now the latest: One Nation. In in that statement the Prime Minister said that he wanted a civilised country where we take care of those in need, where we invest in our children. The best way to take care of those this in need is to provide them with the opporof a job-a real job, so that in the case In of young people they can look forward to a it is 39.2 secure career path. The only investment this Government is of making in young people is sinking money into an education system that often is not providing our young· with the skills to match a fast changing workplace. It is sinking money into training schemes like Jobtrain which, at an annual cost of $120m, has had one of the lowest records of assisting the unemployed back to work among the various programs offered by this Government. The Auditor-General revealed last June that Jobtrain was very poorly targeted, it was poorly evaluated in tenns of outcomes and that the funds spent on it were poorly accounted for. What hope is there for the young unemployed in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement? Mr Broadbent-None.

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: As the honourable member for Corinella says, there is none. Where does the Prime Minister show his commitment to these young people? Sadly, I have to report that for the one in three young people who are currently unemployed, there is no real hope to plan for a better future because all the Prime Minister has really done is to recycle some of the already failed training schemes by diverting almost $60m from the existing apprentice and trainee incentive schemes during the next three years along with pulling $40m out of Jobtrain and $7m from the training skills program and putting those amounts into new schemes. Are young people supposed to have any faith in this sort of recycling tactic? Opposition members-No.

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: As my colleagues resoundingly say, no, indeed. No doubt these measures will also be given some new buzz word title and will be distributed in a new glossy pamphlet. But young people }Vill not be fooled. It is really the same tactiq as has been used in Victoria by the State Labor Government. We used to have a public train system that was called the Victorian railways. The trains were repainted and the system was renamed Vicrail. Then the trains were repainted again and, with another change of title and a new corporate logo, the system was named V/Line. But it is the same train system that does not work and loses nearly $3m a day. Another tactic used by this Government to deal with youth unemployment is to try to deny its existence. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has recently tried to convince the Australian public that youth unemployment is not the severe problem we all believe it is. He has tried to convince anyone who would listen that the youth unemployment rate is only 8.8 per cent. The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) knows that in his area the rate is much higher than that. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has stated many times that this Government will do or say anything to further its cause, and this is a classic case of just that. To reach that deceitful figure, as the shadow Minister for arts, heritage, sport and youth affairs, Senator Michael Baume, revealed in the Senate, the Minister said that the measure of youth unemployment was achieved by taking the official numbers of unemployed as a percentage of the whole youth population when the real measure of unemployment is the number of young people looking for jobs. What the Minister tried to get away with was including in his figures all young people at school or at university plus those not looking for a job. To my knowledge the Minister still has not retracted this claim. I wonder whether this Government is going to use the same creative criteria to try to change the real figure of adults unemployed. Will it include retired people and women at home looking after their children to try to confuse the real figures as yet another diversionary tactic? The Minister may indeed want to change those high youth unemployment figures to try to divert attention away from the problem, but the problem does exist. Ask any of the young people who queue at CES offices; ask any of the homeless, because they are the living testimony to the real figures of 32.7 per cent. All this GOvernment has done is invent figures to pretend that this growing problem of youth unemployment will disappear. It will continue to exist for as long as this Government fails to address the real problems that are causing unemployment, and no amount of fiddling the figures will change that. I have spent hours talking to many young people in my electorate of MCEwen about what it is like to be 17 or 18 wanting to start an independent life, to start a job, and to look forward to their future with certainty, but finding that the jobs they believe they were suited for do not exist. I want to know on their behalf why this Government, which has had nine years to develop a blueprint for the future of our country, has not even done the research to know what sort of workplace we will have in the year 2000 and beyond in order to properly plan on behalf of our youth. I want to know on their behalf what trends the Government has identified for the work force of the future and what it is going to do about them. On behalf of all young unemployed people, I call on this Government to stop all the diversion, stop trying to change the facts and show some real commitment to the future of our country by making youth unemployment our No.1 priority.  p.m.)-One would think that the honourable member for MCEwen (Mrs Bailey) had a monopoly on concern for people who are unemployed. I suggest to her that she look back through Hansard and read what those opposite, when in government, were doing in respect of unemployed people in the period leading up to the 1983 election, She might well want to swallow her words after reading of that experience. It is very clear this afternoon that the Opposition has a very confused approach to this issue. Unemployment is a most serious issue. It is a most tragic and worrying issue for those families which do not have a breadwinner in employment. This Government knows that and, more than anyone else in this country, is conscious of the need to g-nerate jobs for those families. No amount of chiacking from the Opposition, no amount of false testimony, no amount of whingeing, crying and screaming foul about diversions is going to detract ftom the need to generate jobs. Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: COMMITTEE REPORT
text: On behalf of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I present a report on the prescription and supply of drugs entitled Prescribed HealthPart i-Regulation and the Pharmaceutical Industry, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: COMMITTEE REPORT
text: I ask for leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: COMMITTEE REPORT
text: This report, the Committee's first on its inquiry into the prescription and supply of drugs, has had a long gestation. The inquiry was first referred in the last Parliament and its terms of reference were advertised in 1989. Unfortunately, after a good response to requests for written submissions, the inquiry was delayed by the dissolution of parliament in 1990. The recommencement of the inquiry in July 1990 saw yet more submissions and increased levels of interest evidenced by the receipt of more than 130 submissions from individuals, the pharmaceutical industry, the medical and pharmacy professions, State and Commonwealth Government bodies and consumer organisations. The terms of reference of this inquiry are broad. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) asked the Committee to inquire into and report on the legislative and regulatory framework and professional practices influencing prescribing, retailing, supply and consumption of pharmaceuticals; standards for distribution, promotion and marketing; and current information and education on appropriate drug use. The breadth of topics covered by the terms of reference has meant that, for the first time, all factors involved in the distribution and consumption of medicines have been looked at in a comprehensive way. Other inquiries and studies have examined individual components of the overall equation, but this is the first such inquiry to be conducted by the Federal Parliament and I believe that it has provided impetus for many recent changes in the pharmaceutical environment and will result in more developments if the Committee's recommendations are adopted by the Government. Because of the broad scope of the inquiry, the Committee determined that it would table three separate reports, each addressing selected aspects of the tenns of reference. This, the first report, focuses on the current legislative and regulatory controls and responsibilities and standards which should apply to the promotion and marketing of pharmaceuticals. The second report will address the professional practices which influence prescribing and the range and quality of information and education on appropriate drug use as opposed to commercial promotion and marketing. The final report will examine the current legislative and regulatory controls and professional practices which influence the dispensing, retailing and supply of medicines. This investigation into prescription drugs is timely and complements other inquiries and developments being undertaken. In particular, the Trade Practices Commission has released its draft report on the self-regulation of promotion and advertising of therapeutic goods and the Committee is pleased to support the majority of the findings and recommendations contained in the draft report. Whilst the Community Affairs Committee does not consider that there is gross abuse of the self-regulatory powers of the industry, it has recommended that certain areas should be tightened up. In particular, there should be wider exposure of the complaints process and industry code of conduct and more transparency. The Committee has also recommended broader representation on the complaints subcommittee of the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association along with the imposition of stricter fines for breaches of the code of conduct. The Committee believes that a greater proportion of financial resources should be spent on educational, as opposed to brand product, promotional advertising. To this end, we have recommended that pharmaceutical companies provide more information to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority about the amounts to be spent on promotional activities, including the proportion of their promotional expenditure which is devoted to independent medical education. The Committee supports the preparation of ethical principles to assist professional organisations and, in particular, the medical profession in their dealings with the industry and has made a recommendation that ethical guidelines similar to those prepared by the Royal Australasian College of Physicians be developed by the AMA and other specialist colleges. Other initiatives proposed by the Committee relate to the labelling on medicines. One of these, which is designed to assist health professionals and consumers and to encourage more informed drug use, is to make it mandatory that the generic name of a drug be placed on labels more prominently than the brand name. This should reduce confusion about which drug is being taken and minimise adverse effects brought about by taking multiple doses of the same drug unwittingly. The Committee has also made recommendations designed to prevent the obscuring of essential information on labels by pharmacists, and to simplify warning statements that appear on labels. In relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the Committee has recommended that, in order to minimise listing delays, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee meet more often and, if necessary, for longer periods than it does at present. Recommendations also call on the PBAC to make greater use of clinicians in particular disciplines when examining specialist drugs and to increase the overall specialist expertise of the PBAC by reviewing its current membership. Comments and recommendations have also been made in relation to the use of cdst effectiveness analysis as part of the evaluation process prior to listing drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Such analysis should provide a better basis for listing decisions. In the area of consumer information the Committee has recommended that the therapeutic goods administration be responsible for approving and formally authorising information about drugs for use by consumers. This approved consumer information should be widely disseminated and available in a compendium for purchase by the public. In the final chapter of the report the Committee discusses the need for a national drug strategy. Rational drug use relies on a partnership and cooperation between the major interest groups; namely, the industry, health professionals, government and consumers. A feature of the first part of the inquiry was the conduct of a workshop over two days with representatives of these groups. One of the outcomes of this meeting was strong support for a national medicinal drug policy which should have four major components: a viable pharmaceutical industry, high quality products, equity of access and quality of use. In a recent editorial for the Australian Journal of Pharmacy, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services reinforced these four key elements in a national drug policy. The Minister cited costs to the health system and to individuals reSUlting from the misuse of prescription drugs. The Committee has also heard anecdotal evidence about the costs to the health system of prescription drug misuse but very little in the way of hard data. The Minister said: Approximately 40% of all drug related poisoning cases admitted to public hospitals (an estimated 20 000 people per year) are caused by the incorrect use of prescription medicines. It is estimated that between 30% and 80% of all people taking prescription medicines do not take them as directed. The full social and economic costs associated with the inappropriate use of medicines are immeasurable. Some steps have been taken to address this problem. The Government's pharmaceutical education strategy, involving professionals and consumers, is grappling with the identification of major factors contributing to increased consumer awareness and more rational drug use. The Committee's report will assist in this process. The second and third reports on this inquiry will focus in more detail on the need for further education of health professionals and a more coordinated approach to health care in the area of prescription drugs. The Committee will investigate the limitations of drug therapy and the means of encouraging greater awareness of non-drug alternatives. An inquiry of the magnitude of this present prescription drugs investigation requires the dedicated work of both the Committee members, which I am grateful that I have received throughout the inquiry, and the Committee secretariat. The Community Affairs Committee, like most other committees of this House, is ably assisted by the secretariat. I express my personal gratitude, and that of the Committee, to the Committee Secretary, Bjame Nordin, for his fine efforts throughout the conduct of this inquiry. He has received valuable research assistance from James Catchpole and administrative and secretarial support from Shirley Hunter. Their work is also of a high standard and appreciated by the Committee. The Committee looks forward to the concluding two stages of this important inquiry and thanks all those who have been so cooperative in our deliberations to this stage. I ask for leave of the House to move a motion to take note of the report. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: CHILE AND VENEZUELA
text: by leave-I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Eighty-sixth Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference in Santiago in October 1991. I also present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Chile and Venezuela in October 1991. This, of course, was the delegation which attended the Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference in Chile. I think it should be noted by the House again that the Australian delegation played a major role in the conference of the IPU. The Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo MCLeay), is chairman of the Australian group, a member of the International Executive Committee of the IPU and a member of the Inter-Parliamentary Council. That meant that much of his time at the conference was spent in the very important executive meetings that took place. Equally, I am a representative of the IPU on the Committee for Human Rights of Parliamentarians and also the committee examining and monitoring the situation in Cyprus. That took up most of my time. It ought to be noted by the House that under IPU rules only one supplementary item can be dealt with at each conference, and the supplementary item was furnished through the Australian Parliament by the IPU Executive. It was no small matter, in the very fierce competition that took place, to get the item which was of concern· to the delegation and to this Parliament up for debate at the IPU conference. The item dealt with was the role of parliaments in supporting efforts to achieve a greater liberalisation of international trade, in particular through a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round. Although there was some very strong support for that resolution from some of the developing nations, particularly our host countries and countries from Central America, one is bound to express the view that, particularly in many of the preliminary negotiations, while there was a general endorsement in principle, when some of the older nation states of Europe in particular were giving support to the proposition, it was support on the basis that everybody else got onto the equal playing field but them, thank you very much. One has to say that one feels that the equal playing field is becoming an increasingly lonely place for any nation state to venture onto. Nevertheless, I think the debate that took place urged support for a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round. To that extent, I think the general policies have been advocated within the Parliament were advanced. It would be remiss of me if I did not mention the very real work done with women parliamentarians by our two female delegates, who again distinguished themselves. I note the permanent delegate from the Opposition, who has laboured tirelessly over a period of time amongst the women parliamentarians, often without the reward which should be her due. Nevertheless, our two delegates working together produced a major change to rules. I will leave it to them to inform the House of the details of that. In Chile it was refreshing to see the enthusiasm that existed in all sections of society for the emergence of parliamentary democracy and their concern to make it work. That does not mean that all their problems have been solved. General Pinochet is still a figure in the political scene. Nevertheless, one could not help feeling wherever one went that there was a commitment and a concern to see that parliamentary democracy did not fail. I hope the fact that the IPU conference took place in Chile will assist the strengthening of the foundations of parliamentary democracy in that country. The Ministers we as a delegation visited made it very clear that they see themselves as part of the South Pacific region. They hope to playa part in that region and they look forward to closer relationships with Australia at both a political and an economic level. I believe we have established a base from which those ties can be strengthened. In Venezuela, the delegation spent a great deal of time discussing the possibility of Australian companies investing in joint venture arrangements. At one stage we found ourselves advocating, as a delegation, the role of a major Australian mineral exploration company in a very important development that could take place in Venezuela. I would like to finish on this note: in the past the delegation has had cause to complain about what we felt was insufficient SUppOlt from our embassy staff, but on this occasion one could only be full of praise for the efforts of our newly arrived Ambassador in Chile. that Nothing was too much trouble and he gave the delegation his fullest support and all of the backup which was possible in that situation. On behalf of the delegation, I would like to record our thanks to the Australian Ambassador, Mr Mathew Peake. The same can also be said for our Australian ambassadorial representation in Venezuela. Dr and Mrs De Stoop not only welcomed the delegation but also made very considerable efforts to assist us in our work. One should also point out that often it is not recognised that the presence of a parliamentary delegation visiting Ministers of nation states can also prove quite beneficial for ambassadors, particularly new ambassadors. The presence of a parliamentary delegation and its visits to Ministers opens up a whole range of connections which make life a lot easier and facilitate the kind of communication that newly arrived ambassadors often find difficult to obtain in a new situation. To that extent, I think the important relationship between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and this Parliament deserves much closer scrutiny. We undoubtedly benefited from the experience and the efforts that were made by our ambassadorial representatives, but I am pleased to say that I think they felt they obtained considerable benefits too. I commend the work of all members of the delegation: Senator Bill O'Chee, the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the able leadership of Speaker MCLeay.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: CHILE AND VENEZUELA
text: I seek leave to make a statement on the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Eighty-sixth Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: CHILE AND VENEZUELA
text: I say by way of explanation at the beginning that the reason I have not sought leave to speak on the report of the delegation's visit to Chile and Venezuela is that I was not part of that delegation. I of course had the opportunity to participate, as a member of the delegation to the IPU; however, for personal reasons I found it not possible to participate in that delegation. I want to refer to a couple of particular items in relation to Australia's participation in this IPU conference. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) has mentioned that Australia has been successful in gaining a rule change in relation to the composition of drafting committees for IPU conferences. Australia agreed, on behalf of a meeting of women parliamentarians in Uruguay 18 months ago-12 months earlier than the conference that we are referring to now-to undertake to try to get a rule change to require that when compiling the membership of drafting committees there should be some regard to female participation. The significance of this is that items are debated in the plenum but the motion that the conference will vote on in the end is thrashed out behind closed doors by a small drafting committee which usually consists of, at most, a dozen people-it is sometimes smaller. It is at that point that the critical participation is made. There was a feeling amongst the women parliamentarians that on some issues particular dimensions were being overlooked by drafting committees. It is possible to amend the draft resolution when it is considered again by the whole committee of the conference; but in fact changes of substance are rarely made at that stage. It may be that something which a country or group of countries has tried to get into the draft resolution at the drafting committee stage but failed will be attempted again when it comes back to the whole committee, but I do not know of a single instance where that has actually succeeded. I know of only minor changes to the draft resolutions. No change can be proposed when it comes back for debate by the Inter-Parliamentary Council unless that change has already been proposed in the committee. The chances are that if it is rejected at the committee stage it will not be accepted at the Council stage, so in fact amendments are very rarely carried through to the Council. Therefore, drafting committees become very important. That is the reason that the meeting of women parliamentarians in Uruguay in 1990 gave this matt-r some priority. It was agreed that Australia, on behalf of the women, would investigate ways of getting the rule changed. The delegation brought this matter back to this Parliament's group of the Inter-Parliamentary Union and it received its total support. A rule change was drafted and went forward. I had the honour of presenting this rule change at the plenum meeting of the Inter-Parliamentary Council and it was passed unanimously. It is a very simple change which I think bears a little explanation. It adds the words 'and gender' to a clause which now reads, 'Its composition shall take into account equitable geographical distribution and political and gender balance'. I read that out in order to point out that there is already a number of considerations concerning the balance of drafting committees and it is not unreasonable to add that extra dimension of gender. I had the opportunity, together with the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), who was a Government member of this delegation, to participate in the preconference of women parliamentarians which was held on the Sunday before the conference opened on the Monday morning. I think it was a very successful conference. It gave the women members of parliament an opportunity to meet with one another. This is such a large conference that there are not many opportunities for getting to know other members of the delegations from all countries. Women members of parliament typically constitute between 15 to 20 per cent of the delegates to an Inter-Parliamentary Union conference. However, they make up a much smaller percentage of the Inter-Parliamentary Council. The Inter-Parliamentary Council comprises the leader and deputy leader of each country's delegation. As the Opposition's permanent member on the delegation for the life of this Parliament, that automatically makes me deputy leader of the delegation and means that I am a voting member of the Inter-Parliamentary Council. Whilst women may constitute as much as 20 per cent of the delegates, the percentage of the Inter-Parliamentary Council which is female is very low indeed. I would not care to hazard a guess, but I am sure it is less than 5 per cent. So the women have very little voting power, in practical terms, in the InterParliamentary Union. It is therefore very important to have that pre-meeting of women parliamentarians because it gives them an opportunity to get together, to share their views and to make sure that those women who do have a say in other councils of the Inter-Parliamentary Union are familiar with the views and can speak on behalf of women as a whole where it is relevant. It was relevant in relation to another matter, which I intend to raise later. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports has already referred to the matter of the supplementary item on trade and the Uruguay Round which was put forward by Australia. We worked very hard to get that item up as the supplementary item for debate and discussion-that is, supplementary to the two items that were listed already on the agenda. It is worth saying that that item received an outstanding vote from the delegations voting one by one. As I recall, three items were put forward to fill that slot and Australia's suggestion was a very clear winner. I want to add one other comment to those already made by honourable member for Melbourne Ports in relation to the Europeans. I think it should also be noted that there was an amount of professed support for the item from some other countries-notably some Asian countries-which did not have delegates present to vote when it was actually voted on. In fact, delegates deliberately absented themselves at that moment so that when the name of that country was called out there was no-one there to respond on behalf of the country and to indicate how the delegation would be voting. That was a little disappointing, but we live and learn. I suppose that is the way of international politics, and particularly international trade. Nevertheless, I think it is fair to say that it was a very remarkable success for Australia that we got the support we did from the conference. That was done only as a result of a large amount of extremely hard work and a lot of leg work and talking by members of the delegation doing the usual numbers exercise. I think it really paid off in the end. We got support. I wish to raise one other matter, and that the proposal that Australia made for an item to be placed on the agenda for the forthcoming conference in Yaounde, Cameroon. The Australian delegation had agreed to propose to this conference in Chile that the matter of AIDS was an appropriate subject for the conference in Cameroon. That was for a number of reasons, not the least of which being the conference is to be in Africa and the matter of AIDS is such a dramatic problem in Africa, as indeed it is in all countries and particularly developing countries. The extent of its spread in Africa is well known. On behalf of the Australian delegation, and with its support, I proposed this matter to the women's conference to seek the support of women delegates for advocating that their delegations support listing this item for the eighty-seventh conference. The item received that support from the women MPs. It was also proposed at the meeting of the Asia Pacific group, of which Australia is a member, and received support there. Indeed, I was very pleasantly surprised at the strength of the support from China in particular. I notice that the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin), indicates she was surprised by that, too. One is used to China having an image of being rather prudish on the subject of sex, and certainly that has been borne out by my time in China in attempting to discuss matters of birth control and family planning with the Chinese. So it really was not a quarter from which expected strong support. The Chinese delegate made a statement which has really rung in my ears ever since in strongly supporting the proposal that AIDS should be discussed at the next conference. He expressed his belief that in AIDS it possible that we are actually witnessing the beginning of the end of the human race. That is a very strong and startling statement make. Those who have familiarised themselEuropean ves with the pattern of the spread of AIDS will now be aware that it is no longer seen the disease of homosexuals and intravenous drug users. People might, through misfortune, get it from attending to victims of trauma, is dentists may get it or people may get it from tainted blood transfusions. In fact, the spread through women from heterosexual sex and the consequent spread to the next generation-the very large number of children who have been born world wide and are HIV positive at birth-is a very, very worrying and daunting prospect. I have seen estimates that by the end of this century at least 10 million women will have acquired AIDS through heterosexual sex, and there may be as many as 40 million AIDS orphans. However, I digress. As I said, the comments by the delegate from China in that context really are very pertinent comments. There was also support for the idea in informal conversations with people from quite a number of other countries, particularly African and eastern European countries. I certainly did not canvass all the delegations, but a number of countries indicated support for it. However, it did not get support from 12-plus, who really did not want to talk about it at all. There was another item going forward on the environment, and it was decided that they would support that item. The alternative of a matter relating to AIDS was put forward but not debated. In fact, on one occasion when I attempted to debate it I found it impossible to get recognition from the Chair-who, by the way, was a woman. In the event it was not supported by the executive of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and essentially it failed because it was not I supported by 12-plus. The 12-plus group was originally a group of western European style democracies. It was the countries of the European Community plus like-minded democracies such as Australia, New Zealand, the United States and Canada. It is becoming now overwhelmingly a European group. was Australia and New Zealand do play a full role, and I know we get good support from a number of other countries and delegates, but to I feel increasingly it is developing into a group. There are those who would be quite happy to see our role in 12-plus as downgraded in the future. However, not daunted, not deterred, we are going to have another go on that item at the forthcoming conference in Yaounde. We are going to try to get it up as a supplementary item. I do not know whether we have any hope, given that it was not supported by the executive. I think it is certainly worth a try because, as I said, there is some quite broad based support for the worth of debating that issue and looking at what parliaments cooperating world wide might be able to achieve against the spread of the disease. Finally, I want to say a word on Australian participation. Certainly in my time of going to IPU conferences our level of participation has been high. It was particularly noteworthy this time because of the success in getting the supplementary item up. Australia participated in two out of three of the drafting committees. The leader of the delegation, Mr Speaker MCLeay, was our nominal representative on the drafting committee on the supplementary item. I am aware that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports also participated. In what was referred to as the second item on the agenda-namely, human development, economic growth and democracy and the role of parliaments in ensuring necessary links between freedoms, citizens' involvement, economic growth and social investments, which has a very particular relevance to parliaments-I had the honour of representing the Asia-Pacific group. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports was also a member of the Committee on the Violations of Human Rights of Parliamentarians and put a great deal of time into that extremely important committee as well as the committee on Cyprus, to which he has already referred. The Speaker is, of course, a member of the executive committee of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. Australia plays a very active role in both 12-plus and the Asia Pacific groups. It is pleasing to see that the Asia Pacific group is becoming a more cohesive group and is starting to exercise a little more clout in the Inter-Parliamentary Union. Its lack of clout in the past has not been because of the lack of importance of its members, but basically lack of coordination and organisation. On a personal note I would like to thank the secretary to the delegation, John Dyer; Wendy Barnes, who is a member of the Speaker's staff; and Bill Nelson from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, who travelled with us. I would thank John and Wendy for their assistance, and Bill for his assistance and advice as a foreign affairs officer. With the level of participation of the delegation at this conference they were spread very thin. They worked extremely hard and they did an absolutely excellent job. I would also like to thank the Parliamentary Library staff and other Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officers who gave us excellent briefs to enable us to acquit ourselves, as I hope, very creditably on behalf of Australia.

Speaker: Mrs CROSIO
Title: CHILE AND VENEZUELA
text: by leave-I had the opportunity to attend my first Inter-Parliamentary Union conference. I suppose from where I stand, I speak with experience different from that of both the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan). I found the conference extremely useful, not only because of the contribution of the Australia delegation and the response from something like 110 countries, but also one has that opportunity provided to one to participate in the debate that is going on constantly and also in the debate that occurs after a meeting is finished. It was extremely important to a person such as myself to have that first opportunity with respect to what should happen, what one is supposed to do and how one is to take one's part in the debate. Following the very successful completion of that IPU conference, we were then provided with the opportunity both by the Chilean Government and the Venezuelan Government to meet with their parliamentarians and Ministers and, most importantly, to see part of their country, and particularly to look at the areas that we as Australia and Australians could possible be involved with in trade. Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: REFORM AND DEVELOPMENT BILL
text: I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. This Bill, seeking appropriation of some $204m, is introduced to accommodate special circumstances arising from the Government's statement on the economy and employment last November and the recent One Nation statement and to ensure continuity of funding for other important Government initiatives. The Bill addresses only three items of expenditure-labour market program assistance to job seekers and industry, residential care for older people and child-care fee reliefcontinuity of which the Government considers cannot be jeopardised by the timing of the availability of funds being dependent upon passage of Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92 through the Parliament. To await passage of that Bill in the normal course of events would place severe hardship on many individuals, companies and charitable organisations. This is not the Government's intent. In short, payments for these measures are required in a time-frame which, on the basis of current estimates, cannot be accommodated by the Advance to the Minister for Finance whilst awaiting passage of the Additional Estimates. Put another way this Bill principalthe ly deals with the timing of payments for these key Government programs. In light of the appropriations being sought in this Bill I would now foreshadow my 1992 intention to move an amendment to Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92 at the proper time in order to remove from that Bill reference to additional appropriations for these programs. The relevant portfolio program performance statements provided in connection with that Bill will be amended to reflect the changed appropriation arrangements. In that regard, by seeking Parliament's agreement to accelerate separately the appropriations required for these three programs, the Government is responding to the urgency of needs that cannot await passage of the other Additional Estimates in the normal course. I recognise that the Senate, through its Estimates committees, will exercise its customary scrutiny over the range of Government programs in the course of considering Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92. I turn now to the specific programs: Labour Market Program Assistance to Job Seekers and Industry The Government's labour market assistance to job seekers and industry is aimed at assisting the unemployed retain their skills and links with the work force, which is particularly crucial at the present time. The Government announced an increase of $71m in the program for 1991-92 in the November economy and employment statement and a further $lIm net has been provided in the One Nation statement. Smaller increases in related programs, totalling $5m, result in a total appropriation now being sought in this Bill of some $87m, which will be removed from Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92 as I noted earlier. Residential Care for Older People The Government's residential care for older people program is direct-d to ensuring that aged and disabled people who are assessed as being unable to live at home have available to them residential support and care appropriate to their needs. As part of the program, grants are made to religious, charitable and other organisations to defray cost of capital works. An amount of $50m is proposed in this Bill, reflecting a faster path to construction for approvals given. My foreshadowed amendment to Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92 will remove an equivalent amount from that Bill. Child-care Fee Relief The Government's child-care program assists families with dependant children to participate in the work force and the general community by ensuring child-care is affordable for low and middle income families and by improving the supply and quality of childcare. As part of the program, fee relief payments are provided quarterly in advance to service providers to defray the costs of child-care for low and middle income families. This program, unlike the majority initiatives where individual entitlements are met from standing appropriations, is currently funded through the annual appropriation mechanism. In light of the entitlement nature of the program the Government is considering in the longer term whether to establish a standing appropriation for the program. The appropriation sought in this Bill, some $67m, largely reflects an increase in the average amount per place for fee relief since the Budget Estimates were derived and a higher than expected number of child-care places being available in 1991-92. I propose amending Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1991-92 to delete some $43m sought for this program in that Bill. The additional amount of some $24m sought in this Bill reflects updated calculation of the amount required, undertaken since preparation of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92. I wish to emphasise again that this Bill seeks to provide appropriations for programs to ensure eligible individuals and orin ganisations are not disadvantaged and placed in a position of hardship pending passage the Additional Estimates Bills. We have brought forward a specific Appropriation rather than proposing an increase in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to fund (No.1). these programs pending passage of the Additional Estimates. By taking this path the proposed appropriations can be scrutinised Parliament prospectively. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.
