Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN BUSINESS
text: Higgins) (5.40 p.m.)The Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Bill 1992 establishes machinery to allow Australian business regulators to assist foreign business regulators by obtaining evidence, information and the production of documents. It deals with the domestic arrangements to be put in place in Australia for our regulators to assist overseas regulators. It does not deal with situations where foreign business regulators will be requested to assist Australian business regulators. Clearly, however, the substantial part of the object of this Bill is to cooperate with foreign regulators so that they will reciprocate and cooperate with requests that our regulators make to them. Over the last 18 months I have had the opportunity to discuss cooperation between Australian business regulators and regulators in the United States, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and regulators in the United Kingdom, the Securities and Investment Board. In those discussions, the issue of cooperation has been raised with me: from their point of view, they would like information concerning the dealings of particular people in Australia; from our point of view we would like information concerning the particular dealings of people in their countries. Regulators can profit clearly from cooperation. Modem technology and communications have made it easy to deal across international borders, to invest, to sell and to trade. It is possible to buy shares in Australian companies not only in Melbourne or Sydney but also in London and sometimes in New York. It is possible to move prices on domestic stock exchanges through moving prices in foreign exchanges, and that is as old as the Poseidon boom of the late 1960s. The deregulation of financial markets and the movement of foreign currency have obviously also made such dealings easier to undertake; and, indeed, such activity should be undertaken. There is no reason why Australia should quarantine its financial markets; there is no reason why we should quarantine foreign investment; and there is no reason why our companies should be quarantined from investing overseas. But, where the possibility arises that some of those investments or trades might breach overseas laws, we should cooperate in law enforcement. Where Australian companies breach Australian laws by dealings in foreign parts of the world, we would seek foreign cooperation. If there is to be successful law enforcement, we must have the capacity to follow transactions wherever they go and, having followed them, to receive information which is admissible in Australian courts. The interesting thing about this particular Bill is that it is directed at providing assistance to foreign regulators who seek information but not. for the purposes of criminal proceedings. That is made clear in clause 6 where, before a Commonwealth regulator can deal with a request for cooperation, the Commonwealth regulator must secure an undertaking that the information or evidence will not be used for criminal proceedings or for the imposition of a penalty. The Bill is directed towards securing information to be used, presumably, for civil purposes by foreign regulators. Of course, foreign regulators will in many cases be seeking assistance and information to assist in relation to criminal proceedings. I assume that that will be dealt with either under a complementary Act which has already been in existence-the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987-or on another basis. It is important to bear in mind that this Bill and the machinery set up for it predicated on an undertaking being given that the infOlmation . will not be used for the purposes of criminal proceedings. Indeed, the machinery set up by this Bill is to call in a particular person and obtain information, documents or evidence. The Bill is not dealing with the situation where one of our regulators will, for example, just be passing across items on the public record-such as company returns and so on-to a corresponding agency in another country. As I understand it, that kind of exchange of information will have to be done through a memorandum of understanding between the regulators concerned. This Bill will not take away the obligation we have to secure such memorandums of understanding, which we will have to secure to get foreign cooperation back here into Australia. I urge the Attorney General (Mr Duffy) to keep working on such memorandums of understanding and bilateral agreements to secure cooperation for Australian regulators from agencies overseas. The system set up by this particular Bill is that a request will be made to an Australian business regulator and the undertaking will be sought and given. The Australian regulatorwhich, as far as I am concerned, will probably be the Australian Securities Commission and the Trade Practices Commission; there may be others but I imagine they would be the two principal ones-is then required to take into account certain particular matters and form a decision. If after taking into account those particular matters it believes that the request should be complied with, the matter is then passed on to the Attorney-General. The matters that the Australian business regulator is to take into account are such matters as: whether it is likely to be able to obtain the information; the cost of obtaining it; whether the foreign regulator could get material from another source; the degree to which the functions of the Australian regulator correspond with those of the foreign regulator; whether the foreign regulator making the request would be likely to comply with a similar request by the Commonwealth regulator; and whether the matter should be handled under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act. If the Australian regulator comes to the conclusion after taking all those matters into account that the request should be complied with, the request then moves on to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General takes into account another series of statutory factors such as: the national interest; international law; whether the material could be used for punishing a person for an offence of a political character or whether it could be used for punishing a person on the basis of race, sex, religion or political opinion. Those matters are set out in clause 8(2). One matter not set out specifically in clause 8(2)-and I think consideration should be given to setting it out-is whether the foreign regulator has complied with conditions or undertakings imposed in relation to any previous supply of information. It seems to me that is a matter which should be specifically taken into account. If one is going to put conditions and undertakings on the supply of information, then presumably one should take into account in some way whether they have been complied with before dealing with another request. The Attorney-General may say, 'I can take anything into account that I consider relevant and I would consider that relevant, so there is no need to put it in the legislation'. However, certain matters have been specifically speIt out, presumably to direct the attention of the Minister to make sure that he does take them into account and consider them. It seems to me that the Bill could be improVed by making it clear. After all, the only way one is going to be able to enforce these conditions and undertakings is by holding over the heads of the foreign regulators the prospect that, if they do not comply this time, they are never going to get cooperation next time. There is no other practical way of securing compliance with undertakings and conditions. I would think that would be a matter to be specifically taken into account by the Attorney-General when he makes his decision. If the request has got through the Commonwealth business regulator and the Attorney General, the Commonwealth business regulator can take evidence. The way in which that is done is that, under clause 10, the Commonwealth regulator serves a written notice requiring the person to give information, to produce documents or to appear. It has been raised with me that, as an element of fairness in giving that written notice, something should be said about what the request is and what the request relates to. It would not be sufficient, for example, just to say, 'Come in and bring all your documents with you and get ready to answer some questions. The regulator in Panama has been on to us'. As a matter of fairness that written notice should say, 'We have received a request from X. They are investigating in relation to Y. They seek documents that may relate to it in the following way'. It may be that the rules of natural justice themselves will require that to be set out in the written notice, although I would not take that as necessarily the case by reason of the way in which the legislation is put. I raise that again not only for the attention of the Attorney-General but also for the attention of the Australian business regulator. When giving notice, I think in all fairness the notice should say what the matter relates to and give some kinds of particulars as to why the particular person is being called in. I would like to refer to another part of the legislation which fills me with some qualms. A protection against self-incrimination is set out in clause 14, but I notice that it does not include what we know as derivative use immunity. Presumably that is because a Bill is coming forward tomorrow to abolish derivative use immunity in relation to Australian domestic law and there is harmonisation. I must say th-t I have severe qualms about that and I will elaborate on them tomorrow. The privilege against self-incrimination is an old and an ancient one. When we whittle down the privilege against self-incrimination, as is proposed in a Bill to be debated ,tomorrow and as is in this particular BIll, we sho-ld do so only with extreme caution and great care. Parliament is here to consider always the right.'l of the citizen. The rights of an individual-ancient, historical rightsinclude a privilege against self-incrimination. The rights of individuals also include the right to be protected against corporate fraud. That is why it is such a tricky balance to strike. Rights cut both ways in a question like this. It is up to the Parliament to balance those rights. We will be debating those issues tomorrow and I will save my powder, as it were for' tomorrow to discuss that in more detaiL I wish to raise that particularly in relation to clause 14. I think it is necessary for Australian business regulators to cooperate with foreign business regulators. It is necessary to have a system in which that can be done where rights are protected. It is necessary to show good faith if we are, in tum, to receive good faith from foreign regulators. If I have an overall criticism of this Bill, it is that I consider the procedure to be rather cumbersome. It is at least a two-stage process. First of all, a Commonwealth business regulator has to go through matters and then the Attorney-General has to go through matters as well. I know that the Attorney General will be able to apply considerations that the Commonwealth business regulator would not, considerations such as the national interest. But it is cumbersome and I wonder whether it reflects a tension in our general business regulation areas, that is, the tension between where the line for the agency stops and where the responsibility for the Department starts. In this case, both the regulatory agency and the Department are involved. Some duplication will be involved and I think it may cause some diverting of resources, as it were, in the - ttorney­ General's Department to look at thIS, but we will have to monitor as time goes on. On the whole, the Bill has much to commend it. The Opposition will support it. We raise these matters in the debate as matters to be looked at. Some will have to be looked at in the ongoing evaluation as to whether the machinery works. I do not think anybody should be wedded to this particular machinery for ever. I do not think the Attorney-General is. It is a stalt. It is something that will have to be reviewed. I will reiterate that, regardless of putting in place this machinery, it seems to me that if we are to secure cooperation from foreign regulators, we have to continue to pursue on a bilateral basis memorandums of understanding, and I hope they are pursued with all the vigour that can be mustered from the Attorney-General's Department and the other departments concerned.  say at the outset that I welcome the comments of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the Opposition's support for the Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Bill. May I say that I find some commonality with the honourable member on his views about the need to monitor continually the machinery of this process in the future. The Bill is, of course, a necessary and sensible move towards international of cooperation and assistance in administering and enforcing foreign business laws. The global business structure is continuing transmute with the increasing irrelevance of geographical and political boundaries. As that internationalisation of the financial markets counterparts. proceeds, the possibility of undesirable market practices swells and casts an unsavoury shadow over the integrity of markets. If effectiveness of the changes is to be mainwhich tained and community confidence inspired, governments must allow global cooperation with information sharing as a priority. It is longer a viable alternative to stick our heads in the sand of the past. As the Opposition already acknowledged in this instance, it does not believe that we can do so either. The object of this Bill is to enable Commonwealth regulators to render assistance to foreign regulators in their administration or enforcement of business laws by obtaining from persons relevant information, documents and evidence and transmitting such information and evidence and copies of such documents to foreign regulators. Mutual assistance is an important aspect in the internationalisation process which this nation is undertaking. If we are to attain this Government's goal of being an internationally competitive country that continues to strive for world best performance and provides equal opportunity for all citizens, we must all be willing to cooperate and mutually support our international colleagues in their endeavours. By encouraging this outward looking orientation we will be moving towards a more competitive and efficient economy which will benefit our nation. The deregulation of the financial markets, like any newborn, has, of course, gone through some faltering steps before it has gained its balance and contributed greater productivity and competitiveness to our economy. If this momentum is to be maintained, there must be a move towards a cooperative relationship which is embedded in the mechanism of the regulatory institutions. This can be obtained through the legislative process. Importantly, the objective mutual assistance and business regulation can be obtained without significant financial impact. Existing resources of the Australian to agencies will be used, with any additional costs being adequately offset by the advantage of reciprocal assistance from their overseas One of the main agencies which will be involved in this information sharing process the is the Australian Securities Commission, was set up by this Government for the regulation of companies and of the securities and futures markets in Australia. The Comno mission was designed as part of the overall strategy to meet the needs of the Australian has economy in the 1990s and, in particular, it provides public accountability, legislative responsibility and administrative responsibility. The benefits of such a commission are, in the light of this Bill, worth reflecting on for a moment: a single substantive law for all matters governing corporate, futures and securities activities; accountability to a single Minister and Parliament; uniformity of administration through a single administrative unit with Australia-wide coverage; and a uniform administrative law regime. This is just one of the policy initiatives this Government has introduced, and the Bill before us tonight can be seen in that light. The Commission, like its international counterparts, focuses on reinstating certainty in the domestic markets and regaining confidence in the international arena. Confidence is a vital component in the internationalisation process. If confidence is to be maintained it is necessary to promote an uncompromised market. Undesirables must be kept out of the market and, due to the interdependent nature of an internationalised system, it is important to inform and be informed of any possible dangers to that integrity of the market. At present, information sharing exists under voluntary ad hoc arrangements but there is a need to enhance the level of assistance between agencies by developing the right legal structures so as to provide a capacity for those various agencies to gather compulsory information on behalf of another agency in the appropriate case. The need for this mutual cooperation has been heralded internationally. The International Organisation of Securities Commissions in recognition of the impact of internationalisation on the enforcement of domestic securities and futures laws adopted a resolution as far back as 1986 calling for its member organisations to provide reciprocal assistance in obtaining information in respect of market oversight and prevention of fraud. This view was supported by the final communique of the Commonwealth law Ministers meeting in Auckland in 1990, and by the OECD. In Auckland the meeting noted that the voluntary cooperation needed to be reinforced by legislative provisions. The OECD believed that information sharing would meet the need for ensuring appropriate regulation of financial conglomerates. Consequently, the Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Bill represents an acknowledgment of and response to the internationally foreseen need for legislated reciprocal assistance between the world's regulatory agencies. Opposition to these progressive proposals may arise as to the problem of protecting pefsons providing assistance and privacy considerations. However, safeguards have been put in place to ensure propriety in obtaining information, and of course it is incumbent upon us all to continually monitor that. Appearances will be in private with the legislation, under clause 11, limiting the number of persons being present when a person is giving evidence. It states: (a) the person giving the evidence and the person to whom the evidence is given; (b) an approved staff member of the Commonwealth regulator; (c) a representative of the foreign regulator; (d) a person whose presence is requested by the person giving the evidencefor example, an accountant or legal adviser(e) a person who is entitled to be present under a direction given by the person taking the evidence; and (f) a representative of the person giving evidence. Also, persons giving incriminatory evidence or information, as opposed to documents, will not have that information used against them in criminal proceedings. In addition, foreign agencies will also need to acquiesce to this condition prior to any release of such evidence. However, regulators will not be precluded from making such use of any further information they are able to obtain as a consequence of a person providing evidence under this legislation. In addition, the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, and the Archives Act 1983 will continue to apply to the collection and storage of information by Commonwealth business regulators. The proposed scheme will be flexible enough to accommodate the various regulatory schemes which operate overseas. It will be able to take account of the different structures and the varying types of agencies involved in the business regulation, ranging from overseas jurisdictions having regulatory commissions with policing functions to those jurisdictions where the regulatory system is based on a concept of self-regulation. In particular, because of the need to act quickly in a fast moving market system, the scheme is designed to ensure that assistance can be provided quickly and with a minimum of procedural formalities appropriate to the circumstances of a particular request. The legislation has been designed to give optimum benefits with minimal financial impact in an administratively simple and flexible regime for collecting the information. The merit of this legislation is also enhanced by the safeguards which have been introduced to protect persons giving evidence from selfincrimination and will preserve legal professional privilege as well as allowing legal representation. This Government is trying to approach the need for economic and regulatory reforms to promote an international level of efficiency and competitiveness in a systematic and complementary manner. This present legislation will complement the scheme for assistance in criminal matters which is embodied in the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. The legislation will allow our regulatory agencies, such as the Australian Securities Commission and the Trade Practices Commission, to operate more effectively and have a greater capacity to protect our markets and foreign markets from fraud and allegations of disrepute. The benefits of this Bill are self-evident. Not only does it strengthen the integrity of Australia's financial system but it enhances the integrity of both our own and the international financial market. It is an integral in the Government's overall plan to rationalise the collection and sharing of information and evidence and to promote our willingness to cooperate with our international colleagues. In closing, I encourage the House to support the Bill and, in doing so, to help move Australia closer to its place in the international market.

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Title: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN BUSINESS
text: Firstly, I thank the honourable  contribution to the debate. It is an area in which he shows a considerable interest. He outlined the objects behind the Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Bill and what it is going to do in some detail. I thank him for his interest in this area. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) also made a constructive contribution, with a couple of bleeps, one being in relation to what I think we would refer to as the two-stage process, that is, the role of the regulatory agency and the role of the Attorney-General. Just at the end of the honourable member's contribution, and I think this is worth touching on, he somehow seemed to see that as reflecting in some way the tensions between the Attorney-General's Department and/or the Attorney-General and the regulator. That is something that I think is wonying the honourable member for Higgins. I can only say to him that there is not that tension that he refers to from time to time. Sometimes these things can become a bit obsessional. I think it is worth mentioning that there is not that intention, and it is certainly not the reason-irrespective of what the honourable member for Higgins may think-why the legislation is framed in this way. This is not the first time that criticism has been made in the sense of the way the Bill is structured. It has been said, for example, that criticism can be directed at the Bill primarily on the ground that it is overly restrictive, and especially that the regime it establishes will not be acceptable to some overseas agencies such as, in particular, the step United States Securities Exchange Commission. That criticism went along the lines that, because there was a two-stage process in that both-as the honourable member for Higgins indicated-the ASC and the Attorney-General have a role in deciding whether the request for assistance should be granted, the process was too slow and complex. I do not think that happens at all. In fact, the ASCs role quite clearly relates very specifically to operational matters. The request would be made in the first instance to the regulatory agency, and that agency would assess the request having regard to a number of factors. It would take into account the cost of the collection of the information and the likelihood of the country requesting it acceding to a similar request from an Australian agency. Quite clearly, those matters that are taken into account by the agency are operational. It is not a matter of doubling up in the sense that seems to be a concern to the honourable member for Higgins, because when it gets to the Attorney-General for consideration there are a number of broader issues which have to be taken into account as to whether or not request should be accepted-whether accepting the request would be consistent with international law, whether it is in the interthought national interest to comply with the request, and whether the information might, for example, be used to punish or harm a person because of race, religion, sex, political opinions or matters of that nature. So I do not think the two-step approach provides a mechanism which makes the process too slow or too complex. It does not, because it does not represent any doubling up. They are two separate issues. The Australian agency considers matters from a practical operational perspective, whilst the Attorney General's consideration would be based on broader issues which have that broader international perspective which I touched on earlier. It is also worth mentioning that the other point raised by the honourable member for Higgins was the question of the circumstance where, if in the past information had been provided to an overseas agency and that overseas agency had given undertakings that it would comply with certain conditions in respect of the supply of the information and did not, then that should be taken into account in respect of any subsequent request. The honourable member for Higgins referred to his concern that that was not spelt out in section 22. I take that point, but I mention the honourable member for Higgins that I think quite clearly that would be part-as anticipated the answer-of the second phase of the process, that is, the consideration the Attorney-General, because when the ber Attorney-General in that second stage takes into account any other matters that he or she thinks relevant in deciding whether to accede to a request, I think that that would certainly be a matter that would have to be taken into account if there was a record. Mr Costello-Why not spell it out?

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Title: MUTUAL ASSISTANCE IN BUSINESS
text: I take that point. I acknowledge that maybe it should be spelt out. But I must say that I thought it was pretty clear, in the sense that I took the view, in looking at this Bill in the very early days, that that was one of the matters which imthe mediately occur to a person-that, if conditions are not complied with, what would happen in those circumstances. Speaker: Mr SMITH
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill will be supported by the coalition. It is an omnibus Bill from the Department of Transport and Communications and it contains some amendments to the Air Navigation Act, to which the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Ju11) will speak after dinner, the Broadcasting Act and the Radio Licence Fees Act. I wanted to take the opportunity before dinner to make some remarks about the Bill and also some broader remarks about the radio industry. This Bill, in respect of the Broadcasting Act, together with other amendments, makes it possible to ensure that licensees of nonmetropolitan AM and commercial radio licence services who have PM translators will be able to apply under the Act for conversion to FM. My colleagues will know that there has been a great deal of concern in nonmetropolitan Australia to see that PM services are made available in country areas. This Bill attempts to fix up an oversight in the original Act. The second change relates to the radio licence fees, to remove an anomaly within the Act and the new complicated licence arrangements so that the full benefit of an earlier change proposed by the Government and supported by the Opposition where there is a reduction in licence fees c-llected from the radio industry will flow to those it is intended to benefit. In 1991-92 some $8m in reduced licence fees will flow to the industry. It has to be said that the reason the Government has had to address the problems in the radio industry is that the radio industry is now in the worse position it has ever been in. Those people who might be driving home tonight and listening to their radio stations, whether they be commercial or otherwise, ought to know that at least in the commercial area the revenues that have been enjoyed by radio stations-particularly the smaller rural radio stations-have been under severe stress and that some of them have gone out of business altogether. That, of course, has major impacts in regional areas-lack of localism, and so on. There was certainly a desperate need for the Government to respond to the difficulties in the radio industry. That is why we support these minor amendments and why we supported the earlier Bill when the Government presented it to the Parliament. Indeed, on that occasion I welcomed it as the shadow Minister for communications. There is great change taking place in the radio industry. That was brought home to those of us who watched this industry closely through the Australian delegation to the world radio conference in Spain, which returned about a week ago. Some major changes took place on that occasion. That conference went on for over a month and we learnt that a whole new technology will be available called DAB-digital audio broadcasting-and that will include the possibility of cleaning up all this confusion between AM and FM. We will see a dramatic change in the provision of services to regional and metropolitan Australia. As I have said on other occasions, we have to look to a new legislative regime to give effect to these dramatic changes which are being forced on us by technology. This is happening at a time when the financial returns from those in the radio industry are at historically low levels. That, of course, is of great concern to all of us. I think those who were involved in the Australian delegation deserve credit. I have not had a full briefing from the Department yet, although the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon), who is at the table, assures me that that briefing will be forthcoming. In the reports that I have read it is quite clear that Australia did have a major victory in the very complicated area of spectrum management. We have to use spectrum in common with the rest of the world. We have a whole range of new services. DAB is one that I have talked about and mobile phones is another. What are known as LEOS, low-earth orbiting satellites, will be available, which will provide a whole new range of services. We have had some major victories. People such as the Indians and the Indonesians have supported us in trying to get a world regime conducive to the development of these new services. That is particularly important for Australia, because a country of our size with a sparse population, relatively speaking, spread over such a large area needs to maximise to every extent possible the best utilisation of those communication services. The Parliamentary Secretary at the table hosted a conference only last week in Darwin about remote area communications, which, unfortunately, I could not go to. He being from the Northern Territory and I being from Tasmania and having served in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, we appreciate the importance of utilising technologies to their best advantage. So what we are searching for in this Parliament is a legislative regime to give effect to these opportunities. I think we also need to be careful about understanding the difficulties that we have in the current regime; it is old and outdated and it has caused a great deal of frustration for many people around the country. I came into possession of a letter addressed to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal dated 6 March and signed by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) in regard to a licensee in the Richmond area relating to a station called 2LM, which apparently is in Lismore. This is a letter asking the Tribunal to entertain a supplementary licence, at the same time ,as it is dealing with a licence for a 'new independent FM station in the Lismore region. Admittedly, Senator Richardson is the new Minister, but the interesting fact that emerges from his letter is that this independent inquiry from the ABT has been going for four years. There is an AM station in that area, and applications by two competing consortia for independent FM have been going on for four years. Now the Minister has intervened and said to the Tribunal, 'We would like you to join to that independent assessment an application for the existing AM station to have a supplementary FM'. I think that shows us that we have got ourselves into a mess. One can be critical about this, and I guess I have been critical on a number of occasions, but there is a growing recognition that we have to address this problem, because people are being denied FM radio. The policy that we have pursued in this country has meant that a 40-year-old technology has not been made available to many areas in regional Australia. Now we know from the conference in Spain that a new technology is emerging, which means that we are almost going to jump a technology that the rest of the world has enjoyed. I think our approach in radio policy has not only visited a financial disaster upon the industry but also put in place a regime that has not given to the consumer, who after all is the person we want to serve, the opportunity to enjoy even the technologies that are now available. I think the Minister has a major task in front of him to address those problems quickly. Another aspect of the administration of this area is the level of fees, which I raise by way of example to the Parliamentary Secretary at the table, who I know is very diligent in these matters. We are talking in this Bill and in the licence fees Act about a reduction in fees. I received a letter today from a small company called Expamet Pty Ltd of Revesby in New South Wales. Interestingly, it is in the district of Bankstown, which is in the centre of the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I will read the point this small company makes and then get to the nub of the issue, from its point of view. The letter says: This company has been struggling to maintain employment for the 77 people still employed here. Before the recession we just had to have, and despite promises from Mr Keating that the Bankstown district would recover from recession last year, we find that business continues to be difficult to obtain and that profit is rapidly declining. That is true of many companies and small manifest businesses right around the nation. That is something the Parliamentary Secretary at table ought to be regretting. The Prime Minister says that he does, but it seems to somewhat of a hollow claim when he was one who designed the problems that these people face. According to the letter, the nub of the for this company is this: An $800.00 licence fee to cover two walkie talkies and a base walkie talkie, used by our factory despatch and maintenance personnel so that they are in touch with the office gives these mobile stations a status way above reality. The interesting postscript at the bottom of the letter gives it all away. It says: Daily operational time for our 'mobile station' would be ten minutes or less. An amount of $800-plus is paid to the time. Department each year for the two walkietalkies for 10 minutes use a day. It would seem to me that, if we are reviewing the licence fees for radio, perhaps we ought to look at the licence fees for this type of tivity. I think it would be only fair to do so, given that there has been a dramatic change in the technologies that are available. Industry policy and the policies that we are putting forward in this Parliament in Fightback package are all about lowering the input costs to business and saying to businesses that we will address their concerns by taking away payroll tax, allowing them to provide for better labour contracts, and looking at and abolishing the wholesale sales tax range. But we also need to look at the demands that government is placing on place businesses, for example, by the collection data for the Australian Bureau of Statistics, much of which we need, but all of that is done, unpaid, by small business. Here have another example in the communications area of what can only be described as a very heavy impost. Finally, I will take a minute to mention the Broadcasting Act and the changes that are made to it, relating to recent decisions that the ABT has made in relation to children's programming. Admittedly, that does not itself in the radio area, but it certainly does in television. It is not appropriate to the enter into a full debate now about those issues, but I make the point-and I think the be Parliamentary Secretary at the table would the agree-that we are about to enter into a consideration of the broadcasting services Bill, which is in draft form and available for issue community discussion. In the broadcasting area there has not been a more important Bill which has gone to the community for discussion, and will finally come to this Parliament, for 50 years. This will be the first full rewrite of the broadcasting legislation for 50 years. It would ill become either side of the Parliament to take this matter lightly, because we are seeing dramatic changes in technology which are going to impact tremendously on service providers. It will give the opportunity for the consumers to be their own programmers, in We are yet to have the whole debate about pay television and its intricacies and ins and outs. We wait for the Minister, who has just acreturned from overseas, to report to his Cabinet and, finally, to the Parliament. But all of those issues indicate that this is going to be a major change. These matters need to be dealt with sensibly, in an open fashion, and we must make sure that there is opportunity the for full and complete discussion in the broader community. I cannot stress too strongly the major changes that are going to be proposed. There by will be arguments about them, as there need to be, because out of arguments we will get a better Bill. The major changes that will take will require a lot of discussion. Tomorof row or the next day I will be releasing a discussion paper to all my colleagues to draw to their attention the significance of what is we being proposed. What we do here over the next six months will determine the legislative framework for how we deal with broadcasting for a very long time to come. Debate interrupted. SEVILLE EXPOSITION: NA

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I am pleased to take part in this debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I think it is correct to thank the shadow Minister for communications, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), for his contribution and to note that the Opposition supports the amendments to this Bill. It is difficult to see how the amendments could be opposed because they are basically of a housekeeping nature and they do not involve any significant policy changes. Some amendments are made to the definitions contained in the Broadcasting Act 1942 to ensure that certain AM commercial radio licensees, whose main transmitter is AM but who make some transmissions on an PM translator station, can apply to convert their licences to PM in the same way as other AM licensees. I do not think there could be any objection to that. This will ensure that those licensees do not suffer any disadvantage compared with other AM licensees. The Bill also makes a minor amendment to' clarify a drafting inconsistency between paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection 80B(2) of the Broadcasting Act 1942. Part 4 of the Bill amends the Radio Licence Pees Act 1964 to correct a drafting oversight in the Radio Licence Pees Amendment Act 1991. This amendment will reduce by 50 per cent the current licence fee ceiling of 6.5 per cent for licensees with revenues greater than $1Om. Part 4 of the Bill also ensures that the licence fee reductions are applied to two old system licences. Old system licences are not licensed under the Broadcasting Act, but instead are licensed under transitional provisions in the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985. Old system licences require each transmitting facility to be licensed, instead of licensing a service to operate within a service area. As I said before, the amendments to this Bill are basically of a housekeeping nature. The Opposition has said that it does not oppose these and will be supporting them. As we are talking about transport and communications, I would like to expand my comments a little to deal with the transport area in general. As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the efficiency and effectiveness of the transport sector is critically important to the Australian economy-an inescapable consequence of our nation's size and dispersed population. Equally desirable is the need to develop a more equitable society by increasing national income. The Government's guiding objective is the promotion and development of an integrated, effective and coordinated land transport system which reflects national economic and social priorities; pursues safe and efficient practices responsive to user requirements, with each mode undertaking the transport task to which it is most suited; and is equipped to meet the rapid growth envisaged for the 1990s and beyond. The means of achieving these essential goals is structural adjustment through microeconomic reform. Micro-economic reform aims to accelerate growth in living standards. It also seeks to establish an environment where industry can provide, at competitive prices, the goods and services demanded by Australians and by our trading partners. The task in the transport and communications sector is to improve intermodal choice and the links between modes in order to lower the real cost of transport. This directly benefits industries, exporters and consumers. In the transport area, more efficient railways, for instance, would decrease substantially the annual $4 billion drain by the railways on public sector savings and assist some of Australia's largest exporters. Improved efficiency in road investment and management can increase the returns to the community from the Commonwealth's considerable road funding. The Federal Government has also played a pivotal role in initiating road reforms that can deliver an extra $2 billion a year in national earnings. Working in partnership, the Federal Government, the States and the Territories have embarked on a reform strategy that aims to develop a more effective and responsive national transport sector. The basis of this program is the Government's fourth term policy commitment to structural reform of those industries with the greatest impact on the national economy. The impetus is the very real need for Australia to become competitive internationally. Its specific aim is to increase the economy's resilience and responsiveness by enabling higher growth in productivity, production and employment and real wages, and by easing Australia's susceptibility to changes in demand and fluctuating world commodity prices that can destabilise our balance of payments outlook. The Industry Commission has estimated that land transport reform has the capacity to increase our national income by more than $6 billion. The Government is determined to deliver these benefits to the economy and to all Australians. The changes which this Government has initiated and which are now under way are being pursued in a spirit of cooperation with other levels of government and through the establishment of institutions covering the national transport sector. However, more change is needed and at a faster pace. This is not solely a government responsibility, but one which all areas of the community must share. Australian industries and those sectors serving them need to be more efficient. For example, they could increase the return on public funds through better management practices, through more targeted investment, by lifting productivity and, of course, through the use of new technology. The efficiencies achieved can be passed directly to users in the form of lower prices. While increasing efficiency and improving performance in the transport sector, the Government will also act to safeguard public interest, social justice and safety objectives. The pursuit of a modem, efficient and costeffective transport system across all modes has required the creation of new institutional structures in both road and rail, national in outlook and commercially focused. As a consequence, governments are moving towards a consistent national institutional and regulatory environment which is conducive to structural reform and growth. More transparent cost structures will provide clearer price signals in the marketplace. It follows that goods and services will be valued appropriately. Savings flowing from these changes will contribute to a more equitable society through improved national income. Underpinning this restructuring of the industry is a forward-looking infrastructure development program-the largest of its type undertaken by any government in recent years. The Federal Government and the National Rail Corporation have committed $2.2 billion to mainline rail developments in the years ahead. This Federal Government will spend $4 billion on Australia's national road network in the three financial years to June 1994. The Federal Government's land transport strategy and the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) focus this Commonwealth spending on road and rail projects that reduce transportation costs for industry, speed the flow of goods and produce to ports, or demonstrate a capacity to lift national income through shorter travelling times and greater efficiency gains. Having said all of this, it would be remiss of me, coming from the Illawarra region and representing Port Kembla as I do, not to express some disappointment that no mention was made in the recent statement of the two transport needs in the Illawarra: the MaldonDombarton railway link and the Caloola Pass, a replacement road for Macquarie Pass. The port of Kembla will never reach its full potential as an export development port until we get that very' necessary infrastructure constructed. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have been very generous in allowing me to range a little widely from the Bill. But, as I said, it is a rather narrow Bill, dealing as it does with the Broadcasting Act 1942. I worked from the basis that, as it was in the area of transport and communications, I could have your laxity to range a little widely from the transport area. There is no great disagreement about this Bill. Basically, it is of a housekeeping nature and the Opposition has indicated its support for it. Quite frankly, I do not see how anyone could oppose it. I commend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I thought the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) was quite entitled to range a bit. If he thought his terms of reference were narrow on this particular Bill, the section on which I wish to speak tonight, the amendments to the Air Navigation Act, is probably even narrower. Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope you will give me a little leniency. I certainly will not be wandering off the point too much. The amendments to the Act proposed in the legislation relate principally to international aircraft movements in and out of Australian ports and for flights across Australia. It has been quite interesting because up until this time the operations of foreign aircraft have been covered in the Act, while the operation of Australian aircraft flying internationally has been covered by regulation. Basically this amendment ensures that all those aircraft are covered under the Act. There are some related items. All the offences relating to licensed aircraft flying internationally will now be contained in the Act, and there will be an upgrading of penalties for breaches of the Act from the present maximum of $5,000 to a new maximum of $100,000. The Opposition has no problems with that. The provisions of a prison term for serious offences will also be transferred from the regulations into the Act. A proposed new section of the Act, section 13A, will make similar provisions for the operations of scheduled international and non-scheduled charter flights on the same basis as scheduled operations. The only other real change to the operation of the Act is an amendment to section 19, which clarifies that it is an offence for an aircraft flying internationally to, from or across Australia to carry munitions or implements of war except with the written permission of the Minister. There are no new real regulatory powers in this Act, and I notice that the Minister's briefing suggested that there may even be a small saving of money in its implementation. Obviously we would all welcome that. When I first saw this legislation I contacted the people in the Aviation Division of the Department of Transport and Communications who very kindly faxed over to me the regulations and the rules surrounding the licensing of these particular flights. I draw the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Snowdon), who is representing the Minister tonight, to something which interests me. Paragraph 1.5.3 of the regulations state: Any proposed flights to or from the following, or involving the carriage of passengers or cargo between Australia and the following, may not be operated without prior approval: a. South Africa b. Taiwan c. Iraq d. Kuwait e. Cambodia f. Libya I ask: is the Government doing anything in respect of the South African flights and, indeed, the expansion of the flights that are coming from Taiwan at the moment? With the way the traffic is building on the Taiwan run and the estimates of the number of flights that will be applied for from Taipei, especially to Brisbane, if the Federal Airports Corporation can ever get its act together and get some gates available for those flights to arrive, it will be very interesting to see whether or not those carriers will have to go through this. I suppose that, in many respEets, this will be the first of a number of Bills that we will be seeing, and a number of amendments to Acts, as the Australian aviation regime goes through some major changes. This Bill is perhaps the first. There is no doubt that the announcement made by the Government in the One Australia policy, and indeed the policy changes that the Opposition has been promoting for nearly two years, will require a total overhaul of the way we see the operations of international aircraft in and out of Australia. We might have some requirements to make changes to these operations sooner than we think. The revolution in international aviation policy in Australia probably should have begun 11 or 12 years ago. I believe that we have already paid a price for our closed minds and our protectionist attitudes. For decades successive governments, including this Government, have argued that what was good for the national carrier was good for Australia. That attitude was wrong and we have paid the price. While we congratulate ourselves about the strides that we have made in attracting international tourists, for example, to this country over the past 10 years, in hindsight our performance in many ways has been quite pathetic. We still only have 0.5 per cent of the world international tourism market. We can compare that with a place such as Singapore, which has twice the international visitors than we do, or Thailand, which will expect about four times the number of international visitors that we get this year. I think one of the major points that should be made about what has happened in South East Asia, and one of the things that we should highlight, is the fact that we have not been part of that particular action over the last decade. We are operating in the most liberal and vigorous international airline regime in the world. If honourable members want to see what a liberal aviation regime can do, they should have a look at Singapore or have a look at Thailand. It is not about selling our sovereignty; it is about a liberal aviation regime, and we have got lots to learn from that. There is no doubt that competition and efficiency have brought our Asian neighbours great riches, and it is not without significance that the Asian airline carriers are amongst some of the most profitable in the world. But that is history. I am glad to see that the Government is making some tentative moves for a major evolution of Australian international aviation over these next few years. Australia could well be forced into a different situation, too, with what happens in the forthcoming aviation regime of the European Community, which we expect to see at the end of this year. We have already seen the emergence of US mega-carriers; we see attitudes that are still evolving in Asia; and we have seen the marrying up of international carriers into strategic alliances. All those things should be ringing warning bells to Australian carriers who have the chance of really becoming quite small fry in the international aviation regime unless we get our attitudes and our rules and regulations right. I would argue, for example, that the first thing we should be doing is getting a lean, mean, well financed 100 per cent privately owned Qantas that can get out there and compete in this international market. I congratulate the Government on the introduction of dual designators operating for Australia in the international markets. That will produce some international competition, provided all the bilateral arrangements can be changed to accommodate this situation. The other question we have really got to start asking in this country is: how long are we going to have the present bilateral arrangements? It would be my suggestion that we could well see the whole of the bilateral international aviation regime fall over within five years. The EC situation at the end of this year could be the start of it. I have no doubt that, if we see an aviation trading bloc starting in the EC, the North Americans will respond. There is talk about a common market at the end of this year between Canada, the United States and Mexico. If that happens, I am sure Japan can look after itself. We will see the ASEAN countries forming their own trade bloc, and what will be left? It will be Australia, New Zealand and a few Pacific islands, if we are not careful, and we will be very small fry indeed. Aviation has never been included in the Uruguay Round and we have now got a situation where GATT has asked the International Civil Aviation Organisation to submit some ideas to it for the liberalisation of international air rights. The bilateral framework that resulted from the Bermuda agreement of 1946 has to a great degree been the principal reason for the restrictive establishment of these aviation regimes. It is in its final years of effectiveness and, as I said before, if it lasts another five years I will be very surprised. I make the suggestion that probably the only option Australia has got open at the moment is to start making some tentative moves to become part of that ASEAN aviation complex. That is a fairly radical statement, but because of the things that I have pushed out before, and because of the movement of the world to multinational international air rights, I think it is about time we started looking very closely at equipping Australia for the brave new world, especially with the projected growth of air travel in the region. The World Tourist Organisation, for example, predicts that 120 million Asians will be travelling offshore for their holidays by the year 2000. If Australia could get just 10 per cent of that business we would have trouble handling the traffic. Can we do it with the capacity and the finance we have at the moment? If we look at what has been happening to other major industries, such as banking and insurance, we see that the whole thing is becoming internationalised. My suggestion is that Australia should be looking at doing just that with its aviation markets in the coming years. Such a system would demand the most efficient airline operations from Australians, and the best management of airlines, otherwise I acknowledge that there could be some real losers. Frankly, with the present efficiencies of Asian carriers and a newly structured privatised and well managed Qantas, few of the traditional carriers of the US or, indeed, Europe would be likely to be able to compete in this particular region. On the Australian side it would no.t only be Qantas that would be in the game';-lbut Ansett, Australian and any other carrier that may emerge. While some people may say that this is pie in the sky, I remind the House that Australian entrepreneurs have been very much at the forefront in getting this type of situation into place. I refer particularly to the TNT-Ansett organisation and what it has done with international air freight traffic within Europe. The arrangements that TNT has with a whole host of carriers ranging from Aeroflot through to Malev, the Hungarian carrier, through to the French post office, is an indication of the challenge that is there and of the way the rules are changing. I believe Australia has the capacity to get into that particular market and to do it. Indeed, if we want to be part of Asia, as both leaders and both parties are saying at the moment, maybe aviation is one of the doors that can be opened which could give us some of this access into those Asian markets. I have no doubt that a number of Australian airline operators, if they read this speech, will be screaming blue murder, but the plain facts are that if we are going to exist, expand and really get into this business, we have got to start thinking about it now. For those operators who scream and carry on, may I tell them that six of the world's 10 most profitable airlines are all ASEAN carriers. I would stack that up against the perfonnance of some of the Australian carriers in recent years. If they are worried about over-competition on the Australian run, look at the reality of what has happened within Asia. Seventeen carriers compete between Bangkok and Singapore, 11 compete between Singapore and Hong Kong and five operators ply between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. There is no doubt that there is more traffic there, but there is also no doubt that the competition and the efficiencies that have been brought on by the ASEAN have attracted traffic there. It is an amazing situation if, for example, we look at the services out of Japan, that the biggest carrier on, say, the Japan-Bangkok run is United Airlines. It carries more passengers than either the national carrier of Japan or the national carrier of Thailand. What I am saying is that if we do not get in there and start making our mark, we could well see some of the American mega-carriers getting in there, as they are already on the Japan-Australia run under that old 1949 bilateral and we could miss the boat. Competition, open markets and freedom of the skies have been very good news in Asia. That could be brilliant news here for to Australia. As I say, while the amendments this particular Act are only the very beginning of some of the major changes that I think will probably have to make, I am sure that people of good spirits and open minds would be prepared to look at just how we can into that common ASEAN aviation regime, to lift the shackles of the past and to make sure that we go into that brave new world so that Australia and Australians can get the full benefit of what a liberalised aviation regime can bring.

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I welcome the contribution of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) who is a national authority on tourism and aviation appropriately represents the Opposition on these subjects. I believe he made a very good point when he remarked how aviation has changed over the last few years. While we may condemn organisations such as Compass-and some years ago Solo, Bourke's, XL-for the way in which they have in a sense sacrificed themselves to show how deregulation can work, they have made a great contribution. While it could be said that Compass may have priced itself too low, it is quite evident that it did make it clear that we can have lower prices, and things will never be the same again because of the deregulation which took place. The same could be said of other finns which have initiated action. Quite often the previous Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, has been condemned for his role with Solo and Bourke's, and Sykes has been condemned for his role with XL Petroleum, but in each of those cases they took quite historic initiatives which will be recognised by history as forcing down prices. Whatever else is said about all these organisations, they made that great contribution. Of course, the main aim of Hawke with Solo and with Bourke's was to get some price competition. It was the main aim of Hawke, Keating and the whole of the Federal Cabinet at the time to deregulate the airlines for the benefit of travelling Australians, and it was done. Now we see the Government looking at the potential available for lower prices by allowing overseas carriers carry people and the potential we have for to more efficient transport of people in that domestic passengers will be allowed to travel we on internal legs-for example, Melbourne to Sydney, Melbourne to Perth and Perth to Sydney-and also Qantas will be free to get operate domestically. So these are great moves, great changes that are happening. It took too long to happen, but it has happened and it did so under the present Government. Also, there have been some great boosts to airline tourism by the present Government, particularly through promotion, and that tourism is now linking into regions. In this region alone, many of the three or four million people who have visited this place and have come from overseas to see the building that is here. Tourism is now great news for Australia. It is a major part of our export industry. The advertising through Paul Hogan and the advertising through Greg Norman has assured Australia of more customers on aviation, and it has assured Australia of a greater level of tourism which is going to continue. This is quite obvious. The Bill looks at aviation, and the amendments are not particularly important amendments within the context of policy, but they do make some provisions such as replacing the existing general offence provision with specific offence provisions and penalties. They clarify the provisions relating to international airline licences, permissions and approvals, and they enable regulations to be made providing for on the spot fines for specific offences. They remove the power to prescribe in regulations a term of imprisonment. Other speakers have also referred to the reference in the Bill to the Broadcasting Act, which is again making some minor changes. These are in relation to AM commercial radio licence, non-commercial PM commercial radio licence and other matters relating to the Broadcasting Act 1942. I want to make some points about broadcasting because I believe some extremely important things have happened here again through the actions of the present Government which has made some great strides. In this region alone there have been some extraordinary changes. With respect to the areas served by radio, for Canberra, Queanbeyan, Yass and Yarrowlumla Shire the number of radio stations has increased from six to 11 and the number of television stations has increased from two to five. If we look around the region we can see similar progress. In the city of Shoalhaven the number of television stations has gone up from two to five, and the number of radio stations from one to four. In the Eurobodalla Shire where approximately 16,000 people had only one commercial radio station-no ABC radio station at all in 198384-we now see four radio stations instead of one and we see four television stations instead of two. Bombala Shire had no television at all in 1983-84. Now it has a choice of four television stations. Some people in Bombala could receive one radio station and now all can receive two radio stations. Tallagandah Shire had one television station for some people and for others they could not get television at all. In fact, they looked like losing that television station with aggregation and the move of WIN television to UHF. A lot of people would not agree with Malcolm Muggeridge when he said, 'I have had all my television aerials removed. It is the moral equivalent of a prostate operation.' People were certainly missing their television in that area, but instead of that one television station they now have five. Bega Valley Shire, instead of two television stations, has four, and Cooma-Monaro Shire has gone from two to five television stations. Snowy River Shire had no television stations at all but now they can receive four. There are some great things happening in television. The Government is now looking at pay television. It has recognised that the standard of public television will have to be maintained when pay television comes. People will be able to pay for access to television channels which provide music, perhaps; another station may provide drama; another station, sport; another, movies; another, news and current affairs. I am hoping that the ABC will be one of the organisations operating pay television, particularly in news and current affairs. I believe it should be given a go at that. I am worried, though, about the prospect of a funding cut of $IOm proposed by the Opposition because I believe this could well affect rural programs. It could well affect services in areas like Bega and Cooma. It could well affect the local news on Canberra radio stations. It could well affect important activities of the ABC such as its university courses. Let us not go backwards; let us continue the big changes that have already taken place. Particularly let us not go backwards in radio and television services. Let us not have, as exists in the United States, a situation where all sorts of people are able to get radio licences. One sees congestion and confusion there. I can recall seeing one television show which was broadcast from a backyard studio operated by Mqm and Dad; Mum operated the camera while Dad read the news. It was not of a particularly high standard, but there was not much competition. On the commercial stations in the US there is certainly not the range and choice that we have with the ABC and SBS here in Australia. We do not want that dreadful choice which is given to people if they are not prepared to pay for pay television. We need to keep our SBS and ABC services strong. That is particularly important. We do not want the changes that have happened in the United States with regard to the deregulation of airlines. We do not want the accident rate or the safety problems that have occurred in the United States. We need to maintain our safety standards at the same time as we deregulate. Important things are happening in aviation and broadcasting. These amendments are relatively minor amendments, but I welcome the opportunity of complimenting the Government on the way it has moved to reform both aviation and broadcasting.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I am happy to support my colleagues the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Eden Monaro (Mr Snow) in the debate on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill and also to join with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in his thoughtful contribution. I think the honourable member for Eden-Monaro very succinctly summed up some of the issues that arise for an electorate such as his with the need to provide adequate broadcasting services. One of the issues to which certainly colleagues on my side of the House constantly refer is the need to try to provide better services for people in country areas, and certainly for people in remote areas. The whole strategy in recent times has been to improve those services, and I support the honourable member for Eden-Monaro in his remarks about Government reforms of broadcasting. The Government has tried to offer a wider choice. Certainly the ABC has played a significant role in setting standards of broadcasting. Whenever one moves beyond capital cities one is conscious that the ABC becomes very significant in broadcasting. I know the honourable member for Eden-Monaro is constantly aware of that so far as his constituents are concerned. I think these are very important elements. One of the particular concerns I have in relation to this Transport and Communications Bill regarding broadcasting also relates to some particular areas of television. One of the issues raised in recent times has been the move by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to reclassify children's programs. I am pleased to say it has now got sense. Quite frankly, it made a mistake in its approach to the classification of children's programs. Here I refer to the move on the Fat Cat and Friends and Humphrey B. Bear programs. The Broadcasting Tribunal took an attitude towards those programs which meant that Fat Cat would not qualify under the Australian content requirements. It was of concern to many people in the community that these relatively harmless programs were being denied airplay. I ought to be absolutely accurate here. It was not that the Tribunal said that Fat Cat could not be put on air; it was quite simply that it would not qualify for points under the Australian content requirements. So from that point of view I think that the Tribunal saw the error of its ways and said, 'We will leave it to the television stations to undertake their own classifications'. I think that is a more sensible outcome. Children were being denied access to programs which in many senses were relatively harmless. I make the point, and I think it is significant in terms of this legislation, that neither of those programs was particularly insidious in respect of their injection of commercial content. I do have a specific concern about a program on Channel 10 called Studs, which, quite frankly, ought not be on air at that time of day. I say that not because I am a prude but because I doubt whether it qualifies for being put on television at all. It is degrading to women, and I say that very strongly. Mr Snow-Hear, hear! It is.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS

text: In fact, it becomes a commercial meat market. As my colleague alongside me recognises, it is degrading to women, and the fact that it emanates from the United States gives it even less appeal.
