I have raised the issue with the Broadcasting Tribunal, and 1 would hope it will see the error of its ways.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Fat Cat would be far safer.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I think it would be far safer in prime time, quite frankly. The point 1 want to make is that it is very difficult in this Parliament, within our regulatory framework, to be adopting a deregulatory posture in relation to television stations if then, as a consequence of that, the deregulatory environment is abused by putting on air programs like Studs, which really cannot be defended. 1 repeat: it is demeaning to women; it is a commercial meat market on television. In fact, we ought not have it on television. When 1 contacted the Tribunal I was asked whether I was also concerned about a program called Chances. I have not seen that program, although my constituents have raised this matter with me. It seems to me it is probably one of those rather voyeuristic programs. The general drift of television does concern me. Firstly, tllere is the program called Studs, which 1 referred to; secondly, there is the question of the deregulatory environment for advertising. I think that deregulatory environment failed. 1 will guarantee that if there good quality movie on, and I am sure people agree with this, as the movie nears its end the viewer is deluged with advertisements. The television channels cynically play the viewer along and, just as the viewer thinks, '1 had better watch the end of this movie. It only runs for two hours, and I have been sitting here for 31/2 hours already', the television station cynically adds more and more advertisements to try to milk as much revenue as it can. 1 think that is a disgrace. Television stations are simply abusing their position. 1 strongly object to viewers being subjected to that. The Tribunal has seen that that has been a failure and has recognised that we should be going towards a model in which a limit is placed on the number of advertisements shown per hour. Another matter that has been of concern to me for quite some time is ratings. If one was to stop anyone in the street and ask, 'Can you tell when the ratings are on TV?', the answer would be, 'Of course 1 can'. All the good programs are on in the ratings period. The rest of the time there are B-quality programs on. What other commercial organisation could afford to put two quality products on the market? Clearly they only put their A-grade product on the market when the market is being tested; the rest of the time they put a secondary product on. Mr Downer-They have random ratings now.

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: l hear the honourable member for Mayo. The important thing is that this new electronic rating system has improved things. The situation used to be quite farcical in the past. In the summer period there were only repeats and so on because it was not a ratings period. The electronic rating system has improved the situation, and 1 think the viewer is getting a better deal. But it was something that needed to be addressed. For 26 weeks or perhaps even longer-for 32 weeks of the yearviewers were getting good quality programs but for the rest of the year they were being subjected to repeats and B-grade television. All of us in this place must recognise that we owe a responsibility to our communities is a in terms of the quality of programs being broadcast by television stations. 1I have a specific concern about a program called Studs shown in prime time by Channel 10. Frankly, I think that is a program that ought not to be shown, and 1I have complained to the Broadcasting Tribunal about it. I believe that there are other programs that need to be examined for their suitability for television. My third pqint relates to the abuse by television stations in terms of the amount of advertisements they show. The types of advertisements now appearing on television have also been raised with me. In particular, some women are concerned about the advertising of women's hygiene products on television. Frankly, I doubt that those products ought to be advertised on television at the times they are. My final concern is the level of violence on television. I am assisted here by a report by the Broadcasting Tribunal on violence on television. The report says quite clearly that there is considerable concern amongst people in the community about violence. If we do a breakdown in terms of age, education, religious affiliation, family status and so on we see a very real concern about violence on television among many people in the general population as well as among those who were specifically surveyed. I think that much of the violence is contained in American produced programs. I object to that. Quite frankly, it is sometimes quite a joy to watch Australian or British produced programs, which can be quite as dramatic as the American programs but which one can view with a sense of relief because no-one gets shot or beaten up. I feel that the salacious violence injected into Australian viewing by American produced television programs is quite unhealthy. In this respect I am at one with many people in the community, who find that violence quite unnecessary. To use an example, the British produced program The Bill very rarely has violent scenes because the British producers know their game well enough to realise that one can create enough tension and enough drama without having to enact violence. Again, I refer to what I would regard as a magnificent piece of television produced by the ABC called Phoenix. There was one significant violent act in that series when a car was blown up and a policeman and a policewoman were killed. But it has not been felt necessary to inject violence into that program every week. Why is that? Because the producers know their job. Why is it that we so often have to be affronted by American produced programs displaying violence? It is rather interesting to do a body count during the programs to see how many people are murdered. From my point of view and my family's point of view and, significantly, from the point of view of the community at large, there is a considerable rejection of violence on television. I believe we owe it to our communities to look at the program classification system and at the amount of violence which is injected into our television viewing. In the past in Australia we would not have been regarded as a violent society. We were regarded as a vigorous and very competitive society, but not by nature a violent one. I do not believe that we should allow this injection of violence through the medium of television, and largely American produced television, to corrupt our standards in terms of what we regard as a healthy society. It is interesting to talk to children in schools. One can ask them their views on how we should deal with crime. The number of children who respond by saying that you shoot the baddies is rather alarming. In other words, their perception of justice, developed from seeing American produced television programs, is that, if someone is bad, ipso facto, one shoots them. If that is the way that we are developing children's attitudes in terms of violence on television, I believe that we are making a grave mistake. We ought not to wonder when that violence is replicated on the streets of our cities-which, of course, it is. That brings us back to the role of violence on television. I have found the Broadcasting Tribunal research very useful because it reveals the concern of people about violence in the community at large and violence on television. I believe that it is up to our television executives to consider whether they are putting sufficient constraints on violence on television. There is an issue that comes up frequently in my discussions with people. Often movies with an Adults Only classification that are shown late in the evening are promoted-with significant violent extracts-in prime time when children are watching television. We have to ask ourselves whether the television stations are getting around the requirements of the Act and whether they are ignoring the standards that ought to be set for the community. Some television stations argue that stills of violent actions are different from movies of violent action, However, I think the issue that has to be addressed is whether our community accepts that we should have as much violence sho'Yll on television as we do. The answer that comes across in this report, entitled Sex, J!!oien,ce and Offensive Language, is that the VIew ill the community is that there is too much violence. There is a concern about the frequency of bad language on television. There is also a concern about the number of sex scenes on television. Again, I do not say this from the point of view of being somewhat sheltered in relation to what television does, but because television is a very powerful medium that is viewed in many homes in Australia. My concern is, therefore, in two areas. One of my concerns relates to the demeaning of people, in particular women. I refer to programs such as Studs and to violent programs. Secondly, I believe that television executives have a very significant responsibility to look at the quality of what they are putting before us. If they actually talked to people in the community, quite separate from th-ir ratings-:- whic.h the Broadcasting Tnbunal, to Its credIt, has done in this report-they will find that there is a very real concern about what is shown on television. I have not dealt with another area of real concern, the content of news programs, but I believe that that is a big issue that needs addressed. However, I suggest that people sit down some night with a stopwatch and look at commercial television news to see just how much real news they get. Certainly there is a lot of interchange between the tw- talking heads; there is a lot of chit-chat about what has been happening. But in terms of hard content there is very little. Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: Yes. I thank the honourable member for Mayo for his interjection, because he is right. We get very low quality stories. Many people in the community tell me, - SBS news tells me what is happening in the world'. The ABC, when it is doing its job properly, has a properly structured news program. I recognise that there are commercial stations which try to do a very good job with their news programs. However, when one is subjected to only about three significant stories and the rest happen to be cats up trees stories, one wonders whether we are being given sufficient news or whether, in fact, as has been discovered in the United States, news has become entertainment. This is now called 'infotainment'. That is an interesting word because news content is reduced and it becomes more entertainment. What the news executives are looking at is not a program with a real news content but something to entertain their viewers. In the end we have to ask ourselves whether, if viewers are not being properly informed, our democratic society is being conducted properly. I respond by saying that I do not believe it is. A proper democratic society requires proper levels of information, not entertainment posing as news. I suggest to many people that they take a stopwatch next time they watch commercial television news and take a note of how much real news they get compared with chit-chat and cats up trees stories, and how many advertisements are shown during the news to be program. If we went into a restaurant and bought a meal that undersold us in the way that commercial television news undersells us, we would wonder whether we would ever go back to that restaurant. However, people are great creatures of habit, and come 6 o'clock at night they tum their television on to a certain station. I accept that, and it is not all bad news. However, if people such as us in this Parliament do not draw the attention of the people at large to these issues we are perhaps not doing our job. I make these comments about television because I believe they are significant in regard to the broadcasting legislation before us. There are issues that people raise with me on a regular basis in relation to their families, in particular their children, and what is being put forward in the form of television programs. I refer again to programs such as Studs which, frankly, demean women and ought not to be on television. I suggest that the 10 network must be in grave financial strife to have to buy a program that is as cheap and hopeless as Studs. As I have said, I have raised that matter with the Broadcasting Tribunal and, to its credit, it is looking at it. Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: What about Skippy?

Speaker: Mr RONALD EDWARDS
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: I believe the question of Skippy has already been raised by the Premier of Queensland. The honourable member ought not to provoke me, but I am glad that he did. The issue at stake here is that some people in the Broadcasting Tribunal were making decisions about what they thought was fit for us to watch. That is all right. We ought to be looking for better children's television and, frankly, they were trying to do that-although I think they were mistaken. But, in doing so, they were blinkered to some of these other programs that were on television which in fact were harmful to children. That is what excited my interest. What does concern me is that when one asks teachers about how many children watch television programs at night-it is worth doing this-one discovers that many children are watching television as late as 9.30 or 10 p.m. Not only is this bad for the children, but also we have to look at what programs they are viewing. I want to make quick remarks about two radio stations. I particularly want to pay a compliment to the management of a radio station in Perth called Radio 6PR, which is one of the few profitably operating radio stations in Australia at the moment. The managing director, Cheri Gairdner, has done an excellent job in getting that radio station back in the black. I see that it has just signed up a commercial arrangement today with a number of country stations to service that station. I believe that will not only improve their news content but also offer them better commercial positioning in selling products. The other station is interesting because it is Radio 6NR in Perth which is an outgrowth of Curtin University. This station is doing a fantastic job with limited resources in providing services to a wide range of community groups as well as sporting groups which have not been served well in the past. With very limited resources it is doing a wonderful job in providing a service to the community at large. I would like to acknowledge those stations. Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION
text: It is not that expensive in terms of the industry and what is common in this country. Turning to the other contributions which were made during the second reading debate, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) did not really address himself to the issues pertinent to this legislation, although raised a number of important matters in relation to transport, particularly as it impacted upon his electorate. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr rull), as with the honourable member for Bass, indicated that the Opposition had no problems with the amendments which have been proposed, but he did raise a couple of questions about aviation policy. Whilst it is important that we do debate the question of aviation policy, the honourable member for Fadden talked about open skies, a brave new world of aviation and the need for a sudden upturn in the number of inbound tourists to Australia. I am sure that the honourable member would agree with me that the carefully targeted initiatives announced in the One Nation package will provide much of the stimulus which he refers to and contrast dramatically with the proposals which have been made by the Opposition. _ I just remind the House about some of the broad policy objectives for the aviation industry that came out of the One Nation statement: promotion of Australian interests; facilitating tourism and trade; fair access by Australian airline operators to international domestic markets; competitive policy and industry efficiency-both most relevant to the contribution which was made by the honourable member for Fadden. The Government has taken the view that the international and domestic airline industry will be enhanced by creating an environment which will foster, amongst other things, increased competition and pricing flexibility leading to greater economic efficiency in the airline industry free from unnecessary government controls, increased responsiveness by airlines to consumer needs and the promotion of tourism and trade. The Government's policy will, as I am sure the honourable member knows, encourage greater competition both domestically and internationally and the development of a more robust, integrated and internationally competitive Australian aviation industry. It also builds on the already substantial program of micro-economic reform in the international and domestic aviation industry with benefits he for the crucial areas of international domestic tourism and trade and for the national economy. It recognises that the Australian and New Zealand aviation markets are relatively small and that there could be advantages for consumers in both countries and for the ability of our airlines to compete internationally if the two markets are merged. The policy also allows for the privatisation process for Qantas and Australian Airlines to continue with - eater certainty. It provides scope for greater regional diversity of international flights to and from Australia, as well as scope for the development of Australian designated international carriers based outside Sydney. It ensures that airport infrastructure will not become a barrier to growth in the aviation industry. It encourages a vigorous cost effective regional aviation market by accelerating the final transfer of Commonwealth airports and withdrawal from the ALOP; and it recognises that the Civil Aviation Authority and Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will continue to maintain national safety standards. These sorts of changes have been applauded by the industry. Most informed commentators agree that this is the sort of way in which the aviation industry should be managed into the future. I commend the legislation to the House. Question resolved in the afftrmative. Bill read a second time. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: NOES
text: I want to congratulate the coarse grain growers of Australia and through their representative organisation the Grains Council of Australia on this bringing together of the different coarse grain research and development arrangements for their combined or total industry. That is what these Bills, the Coarse Grains Levy Bill and the Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill, do; they bring together all of the different coarse grains. At the present time we have barley and triticale within the research and development arrangements. This brings in cereal rye and oats. Others potentially, as I understand it, to come into the system would be grain sorghum and maize. This legislation is part of the standard rural industry research and development arrangement, through the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act, that is, the dollar for dollar, industry and Government. arrangement up to a maximum PAIRS of 0.5 of the gross value of production for the particular industry. It is particularly commendable that oats and cereal rye, which are just coming into the scheme, are immediately going to the maximum level that attracts the matching contribution from the Government. Barley and triticale are already there. It is my understanding that they will all go higher than what has been the target set by the Government for what is seen to be a worthwhile pJ: a reasonable contribution on the part of the industry to research programs. I believe this legislation also signifies further development in coarse grains and grain industry research generally. I see it as being in three stages. The first stage was when wheat, alone of the grains, had a research arrangement with the Government. Over a period that was seen to be too narrow; the concentration was on wheat when there was a need for research to develop more appropriate strains of other coarse grain varieties to meet market opportunities and also as required for better fann management practices in the wheat-sheep zone of Australia. Of course, that broader concept of grain crops is not just wheat and coarse grain, but also legumes and oilseed crops. The second stage in this development of research arrangements came with the inclusion cif that broader range of grain varieties in the research arrangements. We are seeing some of that still going on, and that is part of this legislation tonight. In this second stage, yield as well as suitable varieties for different climatic and soil situations were the dominant factors. I believe that grains industry research is now moving into a third stage, where the yield is still important but the market requirements are now having a higher priority than before. There are a number of market opportunities for specially bred coarse grain, oilseeds and legume varieties, particularly in that developing market area for us of Asia and the Middle East. One example of this is barley and beer. The growth in beer consumption in Asia is quite astonishing. It is an acceptable form of alcohol to the governments of those countries and it is one that is available to the mass of people. Barley is needed to produce it, and Australia produces very good barley. But there are particular requirements for special beer markets or types of beer. Whereas we have been very successful with China and its beer requirements, and there have been some good joint venture arrangements between some of the Australian barley marketerssome of the barley boards in Australia-and China, the converse is the situation in Japan, where we appear to be missing out on that country's market for barley because the Canadians have bred varieties more suitable for the particular type of beer that the Japanese prefer. The best example of all of these grains and oilseeds, where there has been special breeding using the latest breeding techniques to develop or change a variety to suit particular markets, is canola. There has been a dramatic increase in canola production at the present time where, through some very clever breeding, as I understand it, the ratio of mono and polyunsaturated fats has been changed and maximised so that that is now a very desirable product for a whole range of end uses. With cereal rye and oats coming into the breeding program for the first time, it is interesting that both of these have special appeal in the health food market. Oats are a low cholesterol breakfast food and rye has been seen to be of beneficial value from a dietary point of view for some time. Cereal rye also has the added advantage that it is perhaps the best crop that can be grown in the lighter sandhill-type soils of the Mallee area of Australia. It plays an important part in soil stabilisation as well as growing a worthwhile crop. The Opposition parties will be supporting this legislation. We acknowledge the progress that is being made with coarse grain research and recognise that there is now a need for more special research to pick up these market opportunities. We particularly congratulate the grain growers of Australia. At a time when they are experiencing their lowest incomes on record-for this financial year, minus $32,000 on a farm business basis, according to ABARE, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics-and the tremendous uncertainties and unfairness of a corrupt world grain trade, these people really are setting an example for the rest of Australia. They are saying that our future lies with research because it is through research that we can get productivity and breed what the market really needs in its particular fonns for different end products and different geographic areas. It is not just wheat that is affected by the corrupt world grain trade. Barley and some others are affected as well, and the price effect of the major grains flows on to the other grains. Therefore, even in this particularly difficult economic time, these growers are prepared not only to meet the standard or the challenge set for them by the Government of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production but also to go beyond it. If the other sectors of Australian business were prepared to make the same sacrifices now for long term gain for the international competitiveness of their industry, Australia would be looking forward to a far better future than would otherwise be the case.

Speaker: Mr COURTICE
Title: NOES
text: I endorse the comments of the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), with regard to research and development. They certainly are correct. I had the privilege yesterday of speaking to some of the representatives of the CSIRO about the importance of research and development for agriculture, which is vital if we are to take a leading edge in the competitive world which we are in. The fact that countries such as the United States and European nations are hiding behind subsidies and corrupt world markets makes it harder for us to do that, whether it is under the EEP program or the policies of the EC. I think it is commendable, as the honourable member for Murray said, that at a time when we see a downturn, particularly in the grains industry, grain growers are prepared to put up money for research and development for the long haul, because the long haul is what it is all about. Over the several decades a lot of people from all walks of life have looked to the short term. It will be a long haul if we are to be competitive and improve production with less input costs. The Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992 incorporates the existing barley and triticale research levies and provides for new levies on oats and cereal rye. The levies will attract matching Commonwealth contributions as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. To date, barley and triticale research levies have been imposed under separate Acts which in the main are differentiated only by product specific provisions. The oats and cereal rye levy arrangements will be similar. Consequently, omnibus levy legislation has been developed covering these grains, with provision for other coarse grains to be added by regulation having regard to any recommendation of the relevant grower organisation. The Barley Research Levy Act 1980 and the Triticale Levy Act 1988 will be repealed under the related Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992, which includes provisions to ensure continuity of current levy arrangements for these grains. These arrangements are being implemented at the request of the Grains Council of Australia on behalf of coarse grain producers after consultation with other relevant industry bodies, including the Triticale Grain Association of Australia, which is the representative industry body under the Triticale Levy Act 1988. The GCA is currently the representative industry body for barley and has been nominated as such for oats and cereal rye. Other organisations consulted include the Cereal Rye Growers Association and the various State marketing authorities. Levies will be imposed on grains produced in Australia and will not be payable unless the producer delivers or processes the grains. Grain used by the producer for domestic purposes, whether processed or not, will bexempt from the levy. Maximum and operative rates of each levy are specified in the Bill, with provisions for the operative rates to be changed by regulation on the recommendation of the relevant grower last organisation. The maximum rates may be changed only by Parliament amending the Act. The introduction of value based levies for oats and cereal rye at the request of the GCA reflects the Council's policy of relating the amount of levy payable more directly to the return received by the producer. That is only fair. A value based levy has applied to wheat since 1989. Initially, the operative levy rates for oats and cereal rye will be 0.5 per cent of the value of the grain, with provision for these to be increased to a maximum of 5 per cent of the value of the grain. The Bill provides for the method of ascertaining the value of grain for levy purposes to be prescribed in regulations. It is envisaged that the method will parallel that for wheat. By that I mean pool payments or sale price net of handling, storage and transport costs. Further consultations will take place with industry in drafting these regulations. The barley and triticale levies will continue as specific rates, with the operative rates unchanged at $1 per tonne and 75c per tonne respectively. The maximum rate to which these may be increased by regulation is from $2 for triticale and 75c for barley to $5 per tonne for both of these grains. The Government has made a commitment to continue matching expenditure of approved industry levies on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. While the maximum specific rates proposed for barley and triticale, as requested by industry, generate levy revenue above this level, they allow scope for the operative levy rates to be increased in line with increases in the GDP and to fund and expand a research program. Whilst the proposed maximum rates for the value based levies are 10 times higher than the operative rates, they are not excessive compared with that proposed for the specific rate levies. For example, at the maximum rates estimated, levy revenue expressed as a portion of GDP from the value based levies will be lower than that from the specific rate levies. Regulations to be made under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 will provide for collection of the levies. Other regulations under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 will attach the new levies to the GRDC to enable the corporation to administer the research programs for oats and cereal rye. Additional expenditure resulting from the extension of matching Commonwealth funding to oats and cereal rye will not commence before 1993-94. At the proposed levy rate of 0.5 per cent of the value of the grain, matching Commonwealth contributions' for 1993-94 are estimated at approximately $250,000 for oats and $20,000 for cereal rye. The cost to the Budget of Commonwealth matching contributions for the existing barley and triticale schemes is estimated at $3.1m and $90,000 respectively for 1992-93. Similar outlays are expected in 1993-94. The serious drought in Queensland and northern New South Wales is expected by ABARE to restrict Australian coarse grain production to 6.9 million tonnes in 1991-92. Although there has been some damage from the rains we have had-as the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) recognises better than I-I think they will be beneficial in the long term. It is unfortunate that there has been damage and flooding in the short term; but I think that, in the long term, most grain producers will welcome the rain that will certainly recharge the aquifer and put some decent moisture into the subsoil. Whilst unfavourable planting conditions and poor price prospects for wheat have seen the area planted to barley increase frqm 2.5 million to 2.8 million hectares, production is expected to remain at around 4 million tonnes, reflecting drought conditions during the growing season in northern New South Wales and Queensland. Sorghum plantings are also estimated to have increased from 398,000 to 540,000 hectares, primarily as a result of the current Queensland grain shortage. With recent favourable planting conditions in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales, production is expected to increase from about 0.9 million tonnes to about L 1 million tonnes. Oat production is also expected to remain at around 1.5 million tonnes and cereal rye will remain at about 15,000 tonnes. With wheat planting severely reduced and rain inadequate for normal early summer crop plantings, feed prices have risen sharply. For example, Brisbane sorghum prices rose from about $123 per tonne in February 1991 to about $195 per tonne in October 1991. The price has since fallen to about $153 per tonne in February 1992 as a result of rising confidence of an assured supply, particularly from southern Queensland. Other increases-based on Sydney retail prices-include oats from $93 per tonne in December 1990 to about $158 per tonne in December 1991; barley from $115 per tonne to $159 per tonne; triticale from $113 per tonne to about $160 per tonne; and maize from $168 per tonne to $199 per tonne. High prices could continue until winter crops are harvested in late 1992. I certainly hope that the prices go up and stay up. It will take quite a long time before many grain producers are able to replace machinery and plant and get back on their feet, but it is certainly a more positive sign than we have seen in the past. High prices have prompted the shipment of grain to Brisbane from southern Statesparticularly barley from South Australia. The reduced availability of grain for export has highlighted the expanding feedlot operations for pigs, poultry and beef. I think tant to recognise that because it is value adding. If we are able to use our grains in feedlots and sell the finished product-the beef-to the Japanese or to the Korean market, then we are really value adding. Rather than selling the grain or the grass-fed beef, it makes more sense to get that actual value added for a commodity which the Asian market wants. Coarse grain export tonnages for the 199192 financial year-estimated at 2.4 million tonnes-are expected to be down by about 19 per cent on the previous year. Barley will certainly be down from 2.9 to 2.1 million tonnes, and sorghum will be down from 220,000 tonnes to almost nothing. They represent the major declines. I recognise, as does the honourable member for Murray, that we are facing one of the lowest farm incomes we have had in many years-certainly in our lifetime. That reflects the state of the world's economy and certainly, as I have said previously, the behaviour of the European countries and the United States. I think all eyes will be on the Dunkel agreement and, hopefully, there will be a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round. Unless we can get some sanity into world trade our farmers will always be behind the eight ball because we are so reliant on export markets. It is good to see that on some occasions-' as on this occasion; I will acknowledge it, as I have in the past-there is bipartisan support at a Federal level in regard to trade initiatives. It certainly adds weight to our cause. It is certainly better if we have a unified approach when we take on those large countries. It is interesting to note that 60 per cent of the EEP program in the United States does not go to grain producers; it goes to grain traders. That sort of thing is often missed. I think it demonstrates the inability of the United States Administration to come to grips with the problem. It is certainly living with hangovers from the mid-1930s and some of the Roosevelt programs, which at the time were far-reaching and right in themselves but which are certainly not beneficial for the Western world today and certainly not it is impor- beneficial for us. A point which concerns me and about which I am not able to be bipartisan is the approach to roads and road transport as stated in the Fightback package. On page 58 of the Fightback package it says that over the longer term responsibility for road funding will be transferred to the National Road Transport Commission and roads will be funded through road user chargesMr Lloyd Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Fightback package and road finance have nothing to do with this Bill. It is a fairly narrowly defined Bill, dealing with the coarse grains levy.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: NOES
text: I have the dubious pleasure, once again, of following the chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force. Mr Courtice-Get used to it.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: NOES
text: 1 do not know whether I will have to get used to it after the next election because I understand that the chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force is having a little trouble with his preselection. That might reflect his lack of ability in representing truly the rural people of Australia, which has been clearly demonstrated in the House on many occasions. I tum to the Coarse Grains Levy Bill and the Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill, which are before the House, because I do not want to wander from the point as the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) did tonight. The purpose of the Bill is to impose a levy on certain coarse grains in order to fund research. It introduces new levies on oats and cereal rye. The existing levies on barley and triticale are to be maintained and all of the levies are to be incorporated in a single Act. The levy revenue will attract matching Commonwealth contributions, and I see that as a very positive point. Further, provision will be made in the Act for other coarse grains to be included if recommended by the relevant grower organisations. I notice that the Bill says that the levy is payable when grain is delivered for processing. However, when grain is used by the producer it will be exempt from the levy. I find this a little hard to follow because, clearly, the farmer who produces these grains and uses them on the farm in order to add value to that grain is gaining a considerable degree from the research funded by other people. We do need to monitor the situation where this levy is to be paid at the level where it is delivered to the processor. However, the people who produce these grains and add value to them on the farms-and in many cases they could be used just for feeding livestock-are not required to pay the levy. I believe we have to monitor the situation very closely to see that a gaping hole does not emerge there that would allow a fairly large leakage of funds that could well be going to research. I would like to declare my interest in this Bill at this point because I happen to be a grower of barley, oats and sorghum. Mr LIoyd-Why not triticale?

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: NOES
text: The honourable member for Murray asks, 'Why not triticale?'. Triticale does not grow very well in the rich soils of the Maranoa, particularly around Muckadilla. It may grow well in Victoria, but not in the rich soils of the Darling Downs. So I certainly have a vested interest in this Bill. Only last year I sent money to Canberra to the DPIE for research into barley. I am a great supporter of the need for producers to fund their own research, and this should be recognised by goverrunents and they should match the contributions. The levy rate for oats and cereal rye will be 0.5 per cent of the value of the grain, but there will be a ceiling placed on that, and that is a maximum of 5 per cent. However, barley and triticale are based on a per tonne basis of 75c per tonne for barley and $1 per tonne for triticale. I must say that as a producer I have always been a great believer in a per tonne levy because that allows the industry to determine more accurately the amount of money that is going to be generated by these levies. I just wonder why the industry has agreed on this occasion to vary the methodology that has been used in the past and has gone to this percentage levy rather than sticking to the per tonne levy. Perhaps the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) may have an answer for that. I have always been a great believer in the per tonne levy. It is a bit like a per head slaughter levy, if you like, or a per head transaction levy. It is much better and people are more able to determine the level of funding on a more predictable basis. The coarse grains comprise feed wheat, triticale, sorghum, feed oats, feed maize and feed barley. Together, coarse grains constitute Australia's second most important crop after wheat. Barley is the principal coarse grain, accounting for approximately 60 per cent of coarse grain production. Mr Andrew-Especially in South Australia.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: NOES
text: The honourable member for Wakefield says 'Especially in South Australia'. I must say that when the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and I were on a mission in China some 15 months ago we saw Queensland barley at a malt factory. It was highly regarded and it was preferred over the South Australian malt barley because of its malting qualities. It is an important crop and we saw first-hand that barley being processed in China. I know the honourable member for Murray will back me up on that. It is a valuable export crop, not only for Queensland but for Australia. Triticale is the name given to a grain developed by crossing wheat and rye. Most of the triticale grown in Australia is used in animal feeds, mainly for pigs, poultry and lot feeding of cattle. However, there are uses for triticale for human consumption. It is used in flakes and muesli-obviously it is a health food-for flour, whole grains and speciality breads. It is also used in the manufacture of triticale macaroni. For those people who are conscious of their diets, and particularly sports men and women who need a high intake of pastas, it is obviously very important that we do encourage further production and research into the qualities of triticale. It is really impossible to quantify in dollar terms the value of research and how this research has benefited the Australian agricultural sector, and how it has led to improvements in productivity. Without this research that has been carried out in the past, we would have been left behind long ago in the race to have breeds of cereals such as oats, wheat and barley, and we would not have had products that we could sell on the export markets because our quality would have been much lower than that of our competitors in other countries. What I believe our research must do in the future is move in a direction to reduce the plants' dependency on pesticides. There must be continued research to improve the rust resistant varieties that we have today because we are only now just keeping pace with new rust spores which breed in the fields. We are only just staying in front of the race to get plants which are continually more rust resistant than their parent counterparts. We have to get crops that utilise soil nutrients more efficiently, and this certainly can be done by genetic engineering. It is research of this calibre that will give our grain industry a competitive advantage in the international markets because it is not only price that we are talking about when we are selling these products on the international markets; it is all about quality. It could well be baking qualities or protein levels that are very important. I would like to touch on sorghum and maize because there is provision that in future, if the industry decides that sorghum and maize should also make a contribution to research, those levies could be incorporated within this legislation. It is important that we develop better varieties of sorghum and maize. We celiainly need to develop varieties which are much more midge resistant than the ones we have today. At present the only method of attack that the industry has to combat attacks from pests such as the midge is by the use of pesticides. Unfortunately, where pesticides are used, it is not only the midge that is eradicated, but also the midge's predator, in this case the little wasp. In our research in future years we must ensure not only that we get better yields and better quality grains, but that the plants are better able to resist attacks, in this case from the midge. By relying more and more on pesticides to remove these pests and not allowing nature to take its full course, we will get to the situation where we become totally dependent on pesticides. There is a golden opportunity for us in Australia to be leaders in this field. Unfortunately, we do not have levies at this stage for sorghum and maize, obviously this sort of research is being only by commercial seed companies. It is estimated in Australia that probably only about 10 per cent of the total research that carried out on sorghum and maize varieties is carried out by commercial firms. The balance of it is carried out in Australia by the State departments of primary industry in their plant breeding research programs. It is obviously very limited by the funds it can have access to without a contribution from the industry. This really is directly related to the fact that we have for so long relied on overseas countries for the development of new parent varieties in the hybrid sorghum and hybrid maize plants. We have very much relied on the Texas Agricultural University for this research. In fact, the Texas Agricultural University was responsible in the beginning for the breeding of hybrid sorghums. It is the largest plant breeding university in terms of summer maize and sorghum in the world. So relying on research conducted overseas is not the most efficient way of going about things, and I would urge the grain industry to take a long, hard look at this and come up with some solutions to the way it can levy itself to get more money going into the sorghum and maize industry. Whilst we rely on overseas countries for these new varieties to come on stream all the time, if we want to be efficient we look around the district to see who is the most efficient farmer, who is successfully growing crops, and think, 'So and so is a very successful farmer. I'll do exactly what he does next year'. But the only thing is that next year when we do exactly as he did and we look over his fence, we find that what he has done today we do tomorrow and therefore we are not doing it in exactly the same way as he did it. By relying on overseas research in the sorghum and maize industries, we get the benefits later and much more slowly, and we lose that competitive advantage. I would urge the industry to look closely at the area of levies for sorghum and maize. In the future research with respect to these cereal grains needs also to look at lifestyle. As a nation we can capitalise on our research so in this area because there has been a tremendone dous upsurge in the awareness of health foods, not only in Australia but around the world. As lifestyles improve in'the Asian area is there is obviously going to be an increasing demand for health foods, and cereal grains fit very well into that area. We have only got to look at the significant increase in demands for oats, cereal rye, rye-based biscuits, bread and breakfast cereals. Goodness me, Australia was once a land of steak and eggs for breakfast. Now it is muesli and rye bread toast. Our lifestyle in the last 30 years has changed and almost done a 180 degrees tum; we are going back in the other direction. Therefore, there are huge opportunities for research to improve the varieties of oats and ryes because there are growing markets in both of those areas. It gives farmers the opportunity to diversify into other products other than the traditional ones of wheat, barley and so on but more particularly oats and ryes, and of course this Bill is mainly addressing the levies on these two grains. Research in this area should be directed towards capitalising on this growing awareness of health foods. People are becoming more concerned over cholesterol levels and the obvious way to combat them-we have seen research carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-is by the use of bran in our diets; oat brans, barley brans. All these high fibre diets are not just trendy things to be involved in. They are certainly well proven medically. The other thing with the research is that we can have it as an export commodity. We can sell not only the product from these better crops but the technology of the grains and parent plants to overseas. So, not only is it better for our farmers in that it is going to give them more opportunities to diversify into crops other than the traditional ones we know today, but also if we do have research in this direction-namely genetic engineering which looks at plants which are less reliant on pesticides to eliminate some of the pests that attack them-we could find ourselves at the forefront in this area of research and technology that we as a nation could export. I certainly support the Bill. I do have two concerns about the way the levy is paid, that is, where it is paid at the point of procesindustries. sing and that those producers who use it onfarm will not be required to pay the levy. I think we must monitor that aspect of it to ensure that we do not see a gaping hole develop where people can avoid paying the levy just because they add value to the grain on-farm and yet they derive all the benefits of other people's money. I think we must watch that very closely and monitor it. I certainly commend the matching Commonwealth contribution. It is good to see the Commonwealth getting behind producers' willingness to fund their own research. It is certainly sensible that the Commonwealth does so. I support the Bill.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: NOES
text: I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate in the debate on this Coarse Grains Levy Bill, the purpose of which is to impose a levy on barley, cereal rye, oats and triticale produced in Australia and, of course, to see that levy matched, as indicated by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), by Commonwealth grants. There may be those listening to the debate or even those in the House knowing little about coarse grains who imagine that coarse grains are in some way different from other grains and the term 'coarse grains' implies a certain vulgarityMr Bruce Scott interjecting

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: NOES
text: I thank the honourable member for Maranoa for his interjection. In fact, the term 'coarse grains' does not mean that these grains lack any finesse. One should appreciate that coarse grains are a major contributor to Australia's balance of payments and one of our major export crops. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will be aware, coarse grains constitute Australia's second most important crop after wheat, and barley-one of the grains being considered by this legislation-has earned something like $708m, oats $178m, sorghum $136m, and these rank among Australia's top income earners. This legislation, as previous speakers have indicated, leaves unchanged existing barley and triticale levies and extends the coverage those that exists for research in the barley and triticale industries into the oats and cereal rye As has also been mentioned, the rates will be set with barley at 75c a tonne, triticale at $1 a tonne, and oats and cereal rye will be 0.5 per cent of net farm gate value to a maximum level of 5 per cent. The levy, as the Minister is well aware, will be set by regulation within those particular limits. It is intended that the legislation before the House will enable 250,000 tonnes to be raised for oats research and 20,000 tonnes to be raised for cereal rye research. As is frequently a problem when one participates late in a debate, much of what ought to be said has been said, and the point has already been made by the honourable member for Maranoa, that those who are unfamiliar with triticale ought to be acquainted with the fact that it is a cross between wheat and rye, that it proved attractive because of its drought tolerance and its capacity to adapt to acid soils and, in addition, that much of it is currently being used in the animal feed industry. I think it is significant that we are debating these Bills tonight because we are effectively on the verge of what will be much of the 1992 cereal planting season around Australia. With what have been encouraging-if early, nonetheless encouraging-opening rains in South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland we can expect, if this is to continue, that there might be a large acreage sown to grains in one form or another around Australia, particularly given the rural recession and the need for rural producers to be particularly productive in the 1992 season. In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, it has been suggested that it could well be that we will see wheat tonnages-and wheat acreages, obviously-rise and coarse grain tonnages fall, partially because of changes in crop rotation principally because there has been hesitation about planting wheat because of what have been depressed prices over the last two seasons, and these prices, while not turning dramatically around, look as though they are moving the right way this year. I think it needs to be appreciated that because of the move into beef feed lots and to the value adding that this offers to Australia's primary producers, it is expected that in spite of the legislation before the House and in spite of the enthusiasm for coarse grain production, feed grain is likely to be in even more demand than coarse grains in the coming year simply because of the interest in beef feed lots and the expanding beef market. I want to make a comment or two about the barley industry in Australia because I represent the electorate of Wakefield, and the electorate of Wakefield includes the York Peninsular, the leg as it were-some people say the only leg Australia has to stand onthat characteristic leg of South Australia which claims, not without justification, to be the barley capital of the world. In fact the town of Minlaton, about in the centre of that leg, claims just that title as its town title. I do not want to enter into a debate with my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa about who grows the best or highest quality barley, but it is reasonable for me as a South Australian to be participating in this debate because of the importance of the barley industry in South Australia. I should say that legislation currently being considered by the South Australian Parliament directly affects the barley industry and deals with the issue of whether or not the South Australian Barley Board ought to be appointed or elected. This matter of sensitivity currently being dealt with both by the farmers organisation in South Australia and in the Parliament needs to be dealt with speedily or South Australian growers may well find themselves outmanoeuvred by decisions to change barley administration in the eastern States of Australia anyway. In my focus on barley I want to point out that all the figures would indicate that beer consumption is rising in Asia, and this provides a real opportunity for an expanding export market in malting barley both out of South Australia and in the other States of the Commonwealth. Dr Kavanagh of Carlton and United Breweries has indicated that there are real opportunities for quality Australian barley to be used in this expanding beer market in Asian destinations. I would hope that part of the impetus that will be given as a result of the legislation before the House, and the opportunity for additional funding, will be an impetus encouraged by the Grains Research and Development Corporation to develop barleys which will be marketable for their high quality rather than simply having to compete on price. There is little doubt that quality will be a major consideration as we endeavour to break into malting barley markets, particularly the Japanese market. I think we ought to recognise that what has happened to barley production in South Australia and is happening to barley production around Australia is that as a result of research, particularly varietal research, we have had increasing tonnages of barley available from paddocks that have been cropped year in and year out and available in spite of falling farm inputs. That, of course, is a real credit to research. That is the direction that has been characteristic of Australian agriculture and a direction that ought to be applauded by this Parliament. In fact, it is acknowledged by both sides of the House this evening. Much of the success of farm research has been due to the work that has been done in the paddock and in various selected lots where researchers have been determined in their genetic selection and have come up with superior barley lines that have enabled barley to stand in storms and not shed the grain that normally is shed as a result of storm damage to barley crops. However, as well, the success is the result of what I think has been charactrue teristic of Australian primary productiondence very effective extension. I doubt whether there is another industry in Australia that claim to have been as effective in its extenenthusiasm sion as has Australian agricultural research generally. I know there are many who despair about agricultural research and say there are farmers who are not availing themselves of the latest techniques. There is some justification for concern. But if one looks-and you are familiar with it, Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER - at the changes in farm practice over the last two decades, particularly at the emphasis on the astute use of chemicals in agriculture, one sees as a result of minimum tillage techniques a dramatic increase in production without dramatic increase in inputs. Much of this tribute to and a result of what has been very effective farm extension. Incredibly, of course, this farm extension has resulted principally from the sharing information among farmers. Farmers have been prepared and inclined to take what has been information available from departmental officers and opened their individual farms to field days so that their neighbours may see what are the best techniques to adopt and what effectively works most usefully in area as compared with another area. I think this sense of sharing available research ought to be lauded and recognised. This legislation encourages further research, but the effectiveness of this research and the way in which it is applied to meet the needs of Australia in regard to increased export opportunities will largely be determined by the way that research is made available to farmers. I would like to applaud organisations such as the bureau movements around Australia which, without any political base at all, and without even an agro-political axe to grind, have simply dedicated themselves to making sure that farm groups avail themselves of the latest research, the research that we are seeking to fund here this evening. There are just two other comments I want to make. I want to pick up the point made by the honourable member for Maranoa when he referred to a health conscious society. It is that there has been an increasing depenon cereals in our diet, and that is to be applauded. Of course, we have seen an can increasing demand for oats as a result of the for oat based cereals. This is reflected in sales and in what I hope will ultimately be a healthier society. In my other comment I want to look briefly at the cereal rye industry. This industry has not received a great deal of attention, but in that electorates such as mine and in a State like mine where rainfall is in such short supply, cereal rye has played an important role in ensuring that sandhills that would otherwise be drifting, particularly in the Mallee soils of South Australia, in areas such as Wanbi and spots in the northern Mallee, are locked in a place. Whilst it has been easy for people to is a see the sandhills as being the result of careless vegetation removal by farmers, the fact is that it is those same farmers who are now holding sandhills that previous of generations were not able to secure. Much of the success in stemming the spread of sand drift has been the result of the very careful use of cereal, rye and the development of cereal rye varieties which are drought tolerant and in fact able to - teadily make their way in the face of what has previously been seen as one an unassailable assault of drifting sand. The legislation before the House deals principally with the question of grain research. There are great opportunities no doubt for genetic engineering and great opportunities to develop even more new varieties which will allow us to capitalise on the facilities that we have in Australia to continue to be a major source of food for the rest of the world. I would like to applaud and support the legislation before the House and encourage the emphasis on genetic engineering in the hope of producing high quality grain and of maintaining our reputation as a nation, from a grain trading point of view, well worth dealing with. I support the legislation.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Title: NOES

It will be possible for these levies in the legislation to be converted to value based if industry so desires. In relation to another matter raised by the honourable member for Maranoa expressing a concern that grain processed by the producer will be exempt from levy, I am further advised that subclause 13(1) of the Bill sets out two conditions for exemption, both of which must be met. We have before the House the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1992, which is an omnibus Bill to amend various Acts in the Attorney-General's portfolio. The coalition will not be opposing the passage of the Bill. The Bill amends three Acts: the Judges' Pensions Act 1968, the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 and the Family Law Act 1975. As the adjournment will be moved in approximately eight minutes, I will take the seemingly simple matter of the Judges' Pensions Act first and seek leave to continue my remarks on the other aspects of the Bill on a later day. It is proposed to amend the Judges' Pensions Act to remove the current limitation that a pension payable to the surviving spouse of a judge or a retired judge ceases to be payable on remarriage. Subsections 7(2) and 8(2) of the Act currently provide that, if a widow in receipt of a pension remarries, the pension ceases. Proposed new subsection 8A(I) will provide that a surviving spouse who has lost her or his entitlement to a pension by virtue of having remarried may apply to the AttomeyGeneral for restoration of the pension. The Attorney-General may direct that a pension restored where he or she is satisfied that applicant is in need or that the restoration the pension is otherwise justified. The Attorthat they: ney-General may, in special circumstances, direct that a pension be restored from a date earlier than the date of application. However, that date, of course, must not be earlier than the commencement date of the Act. Where a decision is made under subsection SA(l) not of to restore a pension, the Attorney-General must give written notice of that decision and include the reasons for the decision and want notification of the applicant's entitlement apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review. The proposed amendments will bring the entitlements of judges' widows who have remarried broadly in line with those of widows of public servants and politicians. There appears to be one main difference, which is that the amendments to the Judges' Pensions Act do not give widows who have previously lost their pension due to remarriage an automatic entitlement to the pension. These widows need to apply to the Attorneythe General, who will then restore the pension he is satisfied that the person is in need or that the restoration is otherwise justified. the future, the repeal of the sections prohibiting payment of the pension on remarunderstanding riage will most likely mean that the pension will automatically continue as it does for the widows of politicians and public servants. That is fine as far as the judges' pensions are concerned, but I take this brief tunity to remind the House of this Government's poor record when it comes to judicial salaries and judicial independence. It was approximately a year ago that I referred the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to an extraordinary letter written by the Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, to the Remuneration Tribunal. In his letter Sir Anthony referred to the Government's treatment of the judiciary and in particular the Government's attitude to judicial salaries. Sir Anthony, in writing the proposals to increase the remuneration payable to senior law officers, namely, the Solicitor-General-that was a saga in itself in be addition to the salary that the Attorneythe General sought to pay him-and the Director of of Public Prosecutions, said of the proposals ... indicate a want of understanding of the constitutional position of the judiciary and the relationship which that position requires to be preserved between the judiciary and the Executive Government. More than that, when viewed in light the history of salary determinations in recent years, they indicate an apparent want of understanding on the part of the Government of the nature and significance of the role of the judiciary. That of understanding has led to an erosion of the to remuneration and status of the judiciary. They are not my words; they are the words of the Chief Justice appealing to the Government to recognise the diminished standing of the judiciary that has occurred during the period of this Government. Whilst the Attorney was falling over himself at that juncture to look after the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Solicitor-General-as I say, that was in advance of all the other cosseting he sought to provide for the Solicitor-General-he was, in the words of the Chief Justice, diminishing status of the judiciary, which is fundamenif tal to our system of government. Each time. I have raised the issue, the In Attorney has been unable satisfactorily to enlighten me or anybody else of his of the independence of the judiciary. I remind the Attorney again that the evil of this erosion of judicial salaries will continue as a threat to judicial independence as long as sporadic and partial correction of the process of erosion is left to depend on the opporvery arms of government of which the judiciary should be independent. The judiciary is dependent on the Executive for effective initiation and the legislature for implementation of reform of the present system. There is some merit-I am not proposing it today-in the suggestion that there be an independent tribunal free from government and trade union pressure to determine the appropriate levels of judicial remuneration, subject, of course, to the Parabout liament's constitutional responsibilities. The point is that there is a nexus in this arena which the Attorney has long denied in terms of the standing and status of the judiciary. It continues to concern me, not so much because of the particular levels and types of remuneration, but rather because of the. chaotic and disorderly manner in which they are currently arrived at. I raise these matters again today in the hope that the Attorney will reconsider the misguided position he has adopted on this issue and appreciate that the matter of remuneration bears directly on judicial independence. At the commencement of my remarks I referred to two other pieces of legislation which the Bill also deals with. These are the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 and the Family Law Act, those two Acts, in addition to the Judges Pension Act, being amended by this omnibus Bill. I just say before the adjournment is moved that the Bill in seeking to amend the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act provides that the Minister rather than the Governor General may approve leave of absence for members of the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Tribunal. This will simplify the process of approving leave of absence for members of the Tribunal and really requires no further comment. As I say, the Bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the Family Law Act. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to continue my remarks on another day on the omnibus Bill, particularly as it relates to the proposed amendments to the Family Law Act.
