Contempt Laws: Protection of Journalists

Speaker: Mr COURTICE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to bring to the attention of this House matter which has already attracted. national and international interest regarding our justice system and the rights of Australian journalists. The gaoling of Queensland journalist Mr Budd for contempt of court for respecting confidence of a senior government official deplorable. The actions of Mr Justice Dowsett of the Brisbane Supreme Court must go under the microscope to ensure that the rights of Australian public are preserved. It has been said that the judge in this case was only doing his job and that the law is an as, not Mr Justice Dowsett. I could not agree more. The laws of contempt in this country have been roundly criticised and it is at the judge's discretion what penalty is imposed. the case of Joe Budd, the judge certainly use his discretion. He told the court before sentencing Mr Budd: In all the circumstances, being as lenient as I can be, I order you be imprisoned for 14 days. Lenient indeed! Joe Budd has been in Queensland's most notorious prison since last Friday and, although he has the sympathy of the Corrective Services Commission and its officers, could face no greater threat than coming face to face with criminals he may have reported on during his years as a police and court reporter. Budd is only the second Australian journalist this century to be gaoled for refusing to reveal a confidential source. The other was Western Australian journalist Tony Barassironically he once worked for the same newspaper as Budd-who served five days of a seven-day sentence. These men were bound by their code of ethics, yet the justice system has scoffed at these ethics. I can stand here confidently in this House and raise these important issues knowing that, if I say anything outside the House which could result in my being called before a judge, in this place I am protected under privilege. It is a privilege that is not used lightly but, importantly, in the public interest. Unfortunately, journalists are not afforded these same privileges, but they seek to protect those very same interests. This dilemma between ethics and the law has spurred protests, not only of Mr Budd's a professional colleagues but also those in the wider community who recognise the importance of an unmuzzled media. Australia is a modern democracy characterised by the Joe presence of a free media. The proper the operation of the media relies on the rights, is freedom of expression and access to information. The information is available to journalists from a variety of sources including the dare I say it-high ranking politicians and from people who fear victimisation if they were to be identified. This was the case that resulted in Joe Budd putting his personal freedom aside. Yet the judicial system has ruled that this is wrong. I call upon my fellow members on both of the In sides of the House to help change the law did which put Joe Budd in gaol and to prevent other journalists from facing the walls of a prison cell for simply doing their job. My message is particularly aimed at the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and his State counterparts who have set the reform wheels in motion. These laws must be changed expeditiously to ensure that the public's right to know continues unhindered. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has discussed the matter. A model Bill was drafted and included in a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Bill was circulated and comments sought. A new Bill is currently being drafted by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and the revised draft Bill will be presented to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in July 1992. I compliment the Federal Attorney General and his Department for the work they have put in. It certainly requires the cooperation of all the States to ensure that we do improve this law. I make the point that, were it not for people with courage like Woodward and Bernstein, Watergate would not have been exposed; were it not for people like Phil Dickie, the Fitzgerald inquiry would not have happened. I believe in the proposition put forward by Thomas Jefferson so many years ago: our freedom does depend upon the freedom of the press. That can never be limited without being lost. It is a principle that members on both sides of the House should support and all parliaments should collectively work together to improve this process. As I have said, the Federal Attorney-General is working on that. My thoughts tonight go to Joe Budd who is in Boggo Road gaol. Friedrich August von Hayek: Death

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mackellar) (10.39 p.m.)Sadly, I have to report to the House the death of Friedrich August von Hayek, economist, political philosopher and Nobel prize winner, at the advanced age of 92. Friedrich von Hayek was born in Vienna in 1899 and became a naturalised British citizen in 1938. After 10 years of employment in the civil service and teaching in Vienna, Hayek occupied the Tooke Chair of Economics at London University from 1931 to 1950. Between 1950 and 1962 he was a Professor of Social and Moral Sciences at the University of Chicago. Returning to Europe, he was a professor at Freiburg from 1962 to 1968 and at Salzburg from 1968 to 1977. His Nobel prize for economics, shared with Gunnar Myrdal, was awarded in 1974. Hayek was a towering figure in the economics and politics of liberty and free markets. In his early career before the Second World War he concentrated on relatively technical questions. However, in the late 1930s he turned to more fundamental issues and in 1944 published The Road to Serfdom, which revealed his new focus on the problems of individual values in a world of increased economic controls. He argu-d the case for an economic system based on free markets and a political system granting individual freedom within the law. The interaction between economic freedom and individual liberty was a recurring theme in his work. Hayek was no supporter of laissez faire. Like the thinkers in the Freiburg School of the 1940s on whose work Ludwig Erhard based his revival of post-war West Germany, Hayek believed in a stable and predictable social and economic order within which people would be free to organise their lives. An important element of a stable framework was price stability; that is, negligible inflation. Curiously, Hayek's ideas, which tidied up the classical liberalism of earlier thinkers such as Adam Smith and related the basic principles of liberalism to the modem world, did not begin to dominate the intellectual climate until Hayek's old age. In The Road to Serfdom in 1944 Hayek warned Europe's intellectuals that they were making a grave mistake going down the socialist path. In distinguishing between the state totalitarianism of Stalin, for which they had considerable sympathy, and that of Hitler or Mussolini, of which they disapproved, they were guilty of a grave misapprehension. Further, he pointed out that lesser forms of socialism, such as those practised subsequently by Britain and Sweden, would not work either and if pursued to their logical conclusion would eventually lead to the snuffing out of human freedom. If Western intellectuals had heeded Hayek in 1944 and not, as they shamefully did, heaped him with contumely, an enormous amount of human suffering could have been avoided. The Soviet empire would almost certainly have collapsed earlier and countless Third World countries would not have been encouraged to embrace the disastrous centralist economic models that so many of them did. I urge honourable members who have not read The Road to Serfdom to do so. In it they will get a taste of the extraordinary vision and weather. depth of understanding of this remarkable man. They will also see laid out the explanation of what happened to the world between the end of the war and the collapse of communism in 1989, written during the war and published 45 years before those events reached their climax. Countless millions owe their freedom and prosperity to Friedrich von Hayek without ever having heard his name. Countless more millions suffered tyranny for too long because his words were not heeded. Let this House pay tribute to one of the truly great figures of the twentieth century. Royal Australian Air Force Amberley

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to bring the attention of the House to an event of considerable significance in electorate of Oxley. As honourable members will be aware, RAAF Base Amberley has been an integral part of the Ipswich region many years; in fact, well over 50. On Moncivilians. day, 16 March last week, celebrations were held at Amberley to acknowledge 50 years service to the Australian Defence Force by No.3 Aircraft Depot and 482 Maintenance lived Squadron and to acknowledge the formation of 501 Wing, which is theRAAF's newest and biggest unit. The celebrations included a parade of No. 3 Aircraft Depot's Queen's Colours and the Governor General's banner of 482 Squadron. This parade was the last occasion on which the colours of the two units were publicly paraded, a matter of considerable significance in RAAF history and the history of the Amberley Base. Those who attended included the former Governor of New South Wales, His Excellency Air Marshall Sir James Rowland. The RAAF Air Command Band was flown up from RAAF Base Richmond to take part in the colours parade. There was also a less welcome visitor at the celebrations, with Cyclone Fran making her presence felt. This meant that there was a heavy downpour throughout the whole ceremony which spoilt the day somewhat. However, the RAAF's wet weather capabilities came to the fore, ensuring the success of the event in spite of the bad It was a matter of considerable sadness to many people in the Ipswich region that 3AD and 482 Squadron ceased operations in their golden jubilee year. However, the units have been reformed within the new 501 Wing. No. 3 Aircraft Depot was officially formed at Amberley in 1942 and consisted of one officer and 106 airmen. During its 50-year history the unit serviced over 30 different types of aircraft, including many which have played a vital role in our national defence, such as the Tiger Moth, the Sabre, the Phantom, the Canberra-I think honourable members would have noticed the Canberra at Fairbairn when we arrived here yesterdayAir Base the Iroquois, the Chinook and, of course, the FlI1. The support services provided by the depot my were recognised in March 1980 when it received the Queen's Colours. When the depot was disbanded, it employed over 25 for officers and 650 airmen, as well as 30 No-one can argue that the depot made a significant contribution in ensuring of the operational readiness of the RAAF throughout its 50 years existence. The unit up to its motto of 'Excel', an indication of the high skill level its personnel obtained, having received the Defence Productivity Award in 1990. No. 482 Maintenance Squadron originated at RAAF Base Laverton, Victoria, with the formation of No. 4 Repair and Salvage Unit on 18 May 1942. The unit became No. 482 Squadron with its move to Amberley in 1946, a part of the No. 82 Bomber Wing. During the 1950s the squadron provided support to the wing during the process of conversion from Lincoln to Canberra aircraft. An example of the important contribution this unit has made to the general community is the equipment it prepared for flood relief operations in Queensland and northern New South Wales in its time at the base. The delivery of the first FlllC aircraft to Amberley in June 1973 meant a change in roles for 482 Squadron. The squadron became responsible for the maintenance of the FlllCs used by No. 1 and No. 6 Squadrons throughout Australia in exercises in Malaysia, New Zealand, Hawaii and the United States mainland. No. 482 Squadron received the Governor General's banner in 1981 in recognition of its 40 years of service to our nation's defence. Throughout its 50-year history, the Unit made a sigQ.ificant contribution to the operational effectiveness of the Royal Australian Air Force. It lived up to its motto, 'Trenchant', a word defined in the Oxford Dictionary as 'vigorous, penetrating and decisive'. In spite of its tremendous record of service, it was necessary to merge the two units into the new 501 Wing to meet the logistic needs of the RAAF as the nation enters the twentyfirst century. The two units will shortly be joined in the new wing by the Weapons Systems Logistics' Management Squadron from Victoria. Group Captain Chris Tyler, the last commander of No. 3AD, has become the first commander of 501 Wing. ensuring the historical link between the old and the new units. I am sure that all members of the Ipswich community wish Group Captain Tyler and his Defence Force personnel there well in their new role and recognise the contribution the units that 501 Wing is replacing have made. I am sure that all members of this House join me in acknowledging the fine contribution that the defence personnel of 3AD and 482 Squadron have made to the RAAF in their 50 years of service to Australia. Kangaroo Meat (Question No. 1262) Mr Bruce Scott asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 January 1992: (1) Which countries currently allow the importation of kangaroo meat for human consumption. (2) What efforts are being made to promote the export of kangaroo products. Mr Crean-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Based on information collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Australia exported fresh, chilled or frozen kangaroo meat to the following countries in the financial year ended June 1991: Denmark, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Macau, PNG, Sweden, UK and the USA. In previous years, Germany, Netherlands and France also imported kangaroo meat for human consumption. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service oversees the production and provides animal and public health certification for the export of kangaroo meat for human consumption. Controls over the harvesting and export of kangaroo products are also exercised by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. (2) The direct promotion of the export of kangaroo products is undertaken by individual private companies and details of such activities are not available. Considerable effort by the Government in the past, concerning the promotion of kangaroo products overseas, has been directed at ensuring that accurate information has been provided to foreign governments concerning the management arrangements applying to the harvesting of kangaroos in Australia, particularly as regards to the protection of rare and endangered species. (Question No. 1264) Mr Bruce Scott asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 2 January 1992: Are quails exported from Australia not allowed to be imported into France; if so, (a) why, (b) does the ban extend to other poultry products, (c) which European countries are similarly affected by such a ban and (d) are any chemicals considered in determining regulations controlling the importation of quails into France; if so, what chemicals.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: No (a) While there is no ban on the importation of quails into France, the European Communities impose inspection and certification requirements that are more stringent than those in Australia's export legislation. At present no Australian poultry establishment can meet the import requirements. (b) The requirements for the entry of poultry (which includes meat from live domestic hens, turkey, guinea fowls, ducks, geese, quail, pigeons, pheasants and partridges) into France is covered by the Directive 90/494/EEC on animal health conditions governing intra-Community trade in and imports from third countries of fresh. poultry meat. (c) All European Community member States enforce the Directive. A number of other countries wishing to join the European Community are aligning their import conditions to the Directive. (d) Australia is required to submit a National Residue Monitoring program on a yearly basis to the EC. The export of quails, were it to occur, would need to be included in this residue program. The details of the chemicals and testing levels would need to be negotiated. Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Xes, I am aware of the proposal of the Global Energy Network International (GENI) to use high voltage transmission links to interconnect regional power grids into a worldwide energy grid. I recently met Mr Fisher, Manager of the GENI 92 Conference. Although the GENI proposal may have some merit as a long tem vision, there are complex issues which it has not addressed. For example; infrastructure costs, transmission line losses, technical impacts of large scale interconnections on system stability and integrity. The Australian Government is conscious of the potential economic and environmental benefits of grid interconnection. NSW and Victoria have been interconnected since 1959 and South Australia was incorporated into the network in 1990. The National Grid Management Council, a Commonwealth-State initiative, was established by the July 1991 Special Premiers' Conference to encourage and coordinate the most efficient economic and environmentally sound development of the electricity supply industry in south and east Australia, including grid augmentation and extension. As set out in the "One Nation" Economic Statement, the Government regards upgrading Australia's electricity grid as a high priority as part of a National Electricity Strategy. The Commonwealth is offering to contribute up to $100 million towards transmission infrastructure upgrading, contingent on the relevant States agreeing to a timetable for the development of a National Grid Corporation. (2) No, I advised Mr Fisher of GENI that I do not have the funds available within my portfolio to be able to offer financial assistance to host or cosponsor the GENI 92 conference. I advised GENI that I am prepared to consider in principle support of a non-financial nature for the conference. However, before considering this matter further I have asked GENI for written confirmation from the UN clearly setting out the nature and extent of their contribution towards the conference and their views on GENI. (3) (b) No, the GENI proposal will not be included in the Australian report to the UN Conference on Environment and Development. Speaker: Dr BLEWETT
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: From 12 November 1991 Invalid Pension has been replaced by Disability SuPPort Pension as part of the Government's Disability Reform Package. From November 1991, limited data on the medical condition of clients granted Disability Support Pension has been collected by the Department of Social Security. This, however, is not sufficiently detailed to identify alcoholism or drug addiction which are included in a larger category of psychological and psychiatric disorders. In any event, as this system has been in place only since November 1991, information on the medical condition of the great majority of Disability Support Pensioners is not available from the client payment file and therefore it is not possible to provide the information requested. However, a statistical survey of the medical conditions of Invalid Pensioners granted pension between 1 January and 30 June 1988 can provide some information on medical conditions classified according to the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) 1975 Revision. From this survey, it is estimated that 437 people granted Invalid Pension in the first six months of 1988 had a main medical condition classified as alcoholism (including alcoholic polyneuropathy and diseases of the liver). This represents 2.3% of total grants in this period. As there are no ICD codes identifying drug addiction specifically, information on the grants of Invalid Pension to persons with a main medical condition of drug addiction is not available. National Forensic Science Institute (Question No. 1397) Mr Melham asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 March 1992: Did Mr Justice Morling, in the report of the Royal Commission of inquiry into the Chamberlain convictions, recommend the establishment of a National Forensic Science Institute; if so, what steps have been taken to implement the recommendation.

Speaker: Mr DUFFY
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Mr Justice Morling did recommend the establishment of l! such a body. The National Institute of Forensic Science (NIFS) was set up under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers Council by an Intergovernmental Agreement finalised in February 1991. A Board of Control, chaired by the Chief Justice of Victoria, Mr Justice Phillips has also been set up and a Director appointed. Other staffing and administrative arrangements are being finalised and it is expected that NIFS will be operational in the near future. Briefly, the functions of NIFS are to: sponsor and support research in forensic science of common interest to the parties to the agreement; advise on and assist with the development and co-ordination of forensic science services between the parties to the agreement; gather and exchange forensic information, including through the establishment of a national forensic reference service; support, co-ordinate and conduct training programs in forensic science; and conduct relevant assurance programs.
